Different colored arrows represent various components of the nitrogen cycle and their interactions: green arrows represent the nitrogen fixation process, blue arrows represent the flow of nitrates, red arrows represent the transfer or utilization of ammonia/ammonium salts, purple arrows represent the emission process of NO x , orange arrows represent denitrification, yellow arrows indicate the transfer of energy, and black arrows represent the conversion of dead organisms or animal feces into humus. Graphical abstract Powered by renewable energy, electrocatalytic technology efficiently converts nitrates from wastewater into ammonia, providing sustainable solutions for agriculture, energy, and chemical industries. Ammonia is the cornerstone of modern agriculture, providing a critical nitrogen source for global food production and serving as a key raw material for numerous industrial chemicals. Electrocatalytic nitrate reduction, as an environmentally friendly method for synthesizing ammonia, not only mitigates the reliance on current ammonia synthesis processes fed by traditional fossil fuels but also effectively reduces nitrate pollution resulting from agricultural and industrial activities. This review explores the fundamental principles of electrocatalytic nitrate reduction, focusing on the key steps of electron transfer and ammonia formation. Additionally, it summarizes the critical factors influencing the performance and selectivity of the reaction, including the properties of the electrolyte, operating voltage, electrode materials, and design of the electrolytic cell. Further discussion of recent advances in electrocatalysts, including pure metal catalysts, metal oxide catalysts, non-metallic catalysts, and composite catalysts, highlights their significant roles in enhancing both the efficiency and selectivity of electrocatalytic nitrate to ammonia (NRA) reactions. Critical challenges for the industrial NRA trials and further outlooks are outlined to propel this strategy toward real-world applications. Overall, the review provides an in-depth overview and comprehensive understanding of electrocatalytic NRA technology, thereby promoting further advancements and innovations in this domain. Keywords Nitrate reduction reaction Ammonia synthesis Electrocatalysts Mechanisms Influencing factors 1 Introduction Ammonia (NH3), as an essential chemical product with ubiquitous use globally and is considered the primary precursor for the synthesis of most nitrogen-containing compounds. Ammonia-based chemicals, including refrigerants, pharmaceuticals, explosives, fertilizers, and plastics, are integral to many industries including metallurgy, electronics, mechanical processing, medical care, and agriculture [1,2]. Additionally, as a natural hydrogen storage medium, ammonia has gained considerable attention in recent years due to its high hydrogen content, high energy density, and potential for zero carbon emissions. These properties position ammonia as a promising clean energy carrier, aligning with global efforts to transition toward sustainable energy solutions [3,4]. Currently, the annual global ammonia production is about 175 million tons, with nearly 80% dedicated to fertilizer production [5,6]. With the growth of the global population and the diversification of ammonia-end uses, the global ammonia market is expected to grow from $79.6 billion in 2023 to $120.1 billion by 2032, with a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of 4.54% [7]. The major method for ammonia production worldwide remains the Haber-Bosch process, developed by Fritz Haber and Karl Bosch in the early 20th century [8,9]. In this process, hydrogen and nitrogen are used as feedstocks for ammonia synthesis, requiring continuous operation under high temperatures (500–600 °C) and high pressures (200–500 atm) [10,11]. As an energy-intensive process, the ammonia synthesis industry consumes approximately 1.8% of the global energy output and emits about 5 million tons of carbon dioxide (CO2) annually, accounting for 1.5% of global greenhouse gas emissions [1,12]. Over the past few years, many efforts have been devoted to improving the Haber-Bosch process to reduce its energy consumption and carbon emissions. These include the development of novel catalysts [13–15], efficient ammonia separation adsorbents [16,17], and optimization of the reaction processes [18]. However, further improvements and optimizations of the traditional process remain challenging. On the one hand, the inherently harsh reaction conditions of the Haber-Bosch process impose limits on cost reductions for large-scale industrial production [19]. On the other hand, after a century of development, the Haber-Bosch process has approached its theoretical energy efficiency limit, achieving high maturity and cost-effectiveness for large-scale industrial operations [20,21]. In the context of global carbon control strategies, achieving net-zero emissions, addressing the ongoing energy crisis, and mitigating environmental challenges, finding sustainable and low-energy alternatives for ammonia synthesis is increasingly crucial. New approaches for distributed, clean, and energy-efficient ammonia production are essential to align with global efforts to develop sustainable industrial processes [22,23]. Emerging ammonia synthesis technologies, including photocatalysis, electrocatalysis, biocatalysis, and plasma catalysis, have garnered significant attention as promising next-generation methods due to their unique advantages [24,25]. Among these, the electrochemical route, which uses water as the hydrogen source and nitrogen gas (N2), nitrate (NO3 −), nitrite (NO2 −), or nitric oxide (NO) as the nitrogen source, stands out for its ability to seamlessly integrate with renewable energy sources, providing a sustainable and distributed pathway for NH3 production [26,27]. Recent efforts have been made to improve the performance of the electrochemical nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) under ambient conditions [28]. However, the NRR faces significant challenges, including the strong triple bond of N≡N (941 kJ mol−1), the low solubility of N2 in aqueous solutions, and competition from the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), resulting in low conversion rates, Faradaic efficiency (FE), and ammonia production rates [29–31]. Compared to N2, NO3 − offers several advantages for ammonia synthesis, including weaker N=O bond energy (204 kJ mol−1), higher solubility in water, and stronger reactivity, which together provide favorable kinetics for ammonia formation [32–34]. Thus, the electrocatalytic nitrate reduction ammonia (NRA) strategy presents a viable alternative to the conventional Haber-Bosch process. Its distributed nature and compatibility with variable renewable energy sources can enhance the sustainability of the global nitrogen cycle, as shown in Fig. 1 [35,36]. The electrocatalytic nitrate reduction reaction has been extensively studied over the past decade [35,37]. In general, the NRR involves the generation of NH3 as the primary product through both direct and indirect reduction pathways, mediated by electrons and hydrogen radicals (·H), respectively [38]. However, these reactive species are also susceptible to undesired consumption via the HER, specifically through electrochemical desorption (Heyrovsky reaction) and chemical desorption (Tafel reaction) [39]. Therefore, it is generally believed that the FE and ammonia yields of the electrocatalytic NRA reaction are reduced by competitive HER and the formation of undesirable N2 byproducts [38,40]. In this context, the rational design and development of electrocatalysts with high activity and selectivity are essential for enhancing the electrocatalytic NRA performance [41,42]. To achieve this, it is critical to explore the underlying mechanisms of the NRA process and identify the factors that influence catalytic selectivity during electrocatalysis. This review delves into the reaction mechanism of electrocatalytic nitrate reduction, with a focus on the key steps that determine the reaction rate and the various intermediates formed throughout the process. In light of recent research developments, this review also provides an in-depth analysis of the critical factors influencing NRA performance and selectivity, including electrolyte properties, electrode materials, and reactor design, as shown in Fig. 2 . Additionally, the review summarizes recent laboratory findings and evaluates the potential and challenges of scaling up the electrocatalytic nitrate reduction strategy for industrial applications. By offering insights into the interplay between reaction mechanisms and practical considerations, this review aims to foster innovative and sustainable approaches to electrocatalytic nitrate conversion. Furthermore, it provides theoretical guidance for achieving efficient and scalable ammonia synthesis through electrocatalytic nitrate reduction. 2 Foundation of electrocatalytic NO x to NH3 The electrochemical NRA is a complex process involving an eight-electron transfer and nine-proton transfer pathway. This intricate mechanism encompasses multiple intermediates, such as nitrite, hydrazine, nitric oxide, nitrous oxide, hydroxylamine [34,43–45]. In this process, the source of the proton donor depends on the specific conditions of the reaction system and originates from either H2O or H+ in the solution. Under standard conditions, N2 and NH3 are the most thermodynamically stable forms of nitrogen, especially at pH levels between 6 and 9 [38]. Therefore, they are typically considered the final products of the NRA process (Fig. 2). The mechanisms leading to these products are described in pathways Eqs. (1)–(4) [46–48], with NH3 readily dissolving in water to form NH4 + (Eq. (5)). (1) N O 3 - + 3 H 2 O + 5 e - → 1 2 N 2 + 6 O H - ; E 0 = 0.26 V v e r s u s S H E (2) 2 N O 3 - + 12 H + + 10 e - → N 2 ( a q ) + 6 H 2 O ; E 0 = 1.17 V v e r s u s S H E (3) N O 3 - + 6 H 2 O + 8 e - → N H 3 + 9 O H - ; E 0 = - 0.12 V v e r s u s S H E (4) N O 3 - + 9 H + + 8 e - → N H 3 + 3 H 2 O ; E 0 = 0.69 V v e r s u s S H E (5) N H 3 + H + ↔ N H 4 + ; p K a = 9.25 A comprehensive understanding of the complex electron transfer mechanisms and the formation of intermediates with different oxidation states is crucial for elucidating the intermediate steps and pathways of the NRA reactions. Fig. 3 provides a detailed elaboration of the various potential mechanisms and key reaction steps involved in the electrochemical reduction of nitrate in water [49]. It highlights the multistep pathways transitioning from nitrate to nitrite, and subsequently to ammonia and other nitrogen compounds, offering valuable insights into the behavior of nitrates in an electrochemical environment. The following sections will further discuss the roles of these mechanisms in the electrochemical reduction of nitrates, emphasizing their interrelationships, the rate-limiting steps and kinetic characteristics associated with ammonia synthesis. Given the ubiquitous presence of H+ in electrochemical environments and its pivotal role in proton transfer, most studies focus exclusively on H+ as the proton donor in the mechanism analysis to simplify the model and facilitate a deeper analysis of reaction kinetics and selectivity. 2.1 Nitrate adsorption The adsorption of NO3 − on the surface of cathodic electrocatalysts represents the initial step of the reaction and is also one of the key factors determining the overall reaction rate [48]. The adsorption process is rapid and reversible but is significantly influenced by competitive adsorption effects, where co-adsorbed ions in the solution can inhibit the overall reduction reaction [51,52]. The characteristics of the catalyst surface also play a crucial role in nitrate adsorption. Studies by Tong et al. have shown that the higher the concentration of competitive anions such as chloride and sulfate in the solution, the lower the adsorption efficiency of NO3 −, and the slower the conversion efficiency [53]. The theoretical screening results by Ma et al. indicate that the adsorption energy of NO3 − on cobalt ions at the catalyst surface is more negative compared to other transition metal ions such as Mn, Cu, and Fe, suggesting that cobalt ions exhibit a more pronounced adsorption advantage in the NO3 − adsorption process. This finding further demonstrates the critical role of catalyst surface properties in the adsorption of NO3 −. In addition, the mass transfer of NO3 − from the solution to the electrode surface limits its adsorption and binding concentration on the electrode surface, thereby affecting the overall nitrate reduction reaction rate. This indicates that electrocatalytic NRA is a mass transfer-limited process, with the reaction rate strongly correlated to the initial NO3 − concentration in the solution (discussed later). The reaction process can be described by Eq. (6) (6) N O 3 ( a q ) - ↔ N O 3 ( a d s ) - 2.2 Electrochemical reduction of nitrate to nitrite: Rate-limiting step Once adsorbed onto the electrode surface, NO3 − undergoes reduction to NO2 − (ad) via an electron transfer pathway, which is considered the rate-determining step of electrocatalytic NRA [54,55]. Eq. (7) describes the overall electron transfer process in this step, where the formation of NO2 − involves an initial two-electron transfer. NO2 − (ad) is the primary quasi-stable intermediate formed during the electrochemical reduction process before the complete reduction of NO3 − to NH3 or N2 [38]. As a result, both the ammonia synthesis pathway and the N2 production pathway share a common sequence of events: the adsorption of NO3 − onto the electrode surface, followed by the rate-limiting reduction of NO3 − (ad) to NO2 − (ad). Although the electrochemical reduction of adsorbed NO3 − (ad) to NO2 − (ad) can be generally represented by Eq. (7), the practical reaction process proceeds via a three-step electrochemical-chemical-electrochemical (ECE) mechanism (Eqs. (8)–(10)) [38]. In each step, the fundamental electron transfer reaction produces the short-lived adsorbed intermediate. Throughout the ECE process of reducing NO3 − (ad) to NO2 − (ad), when the chemical reaction (Eq. (9)) proceeds sufficiently rapidly, the two-electron transfer process becomes irreversible [56]. Additionally, some studies suggest the slow kinetics of Eq. (7) are attributed to the high energy of the lowest unoccupied molecular π* orbital (LUMOπ*) of NO3 −. This elevated LUMOπ* energy limits electron injection efficiency, thereby reducing the rate of NO3 − (ad) conversion to NO2 − (ad) [49]. (7) N O 3 - + 2 H + + 2 e - → N O 2 - + H 2 ; E 0 = 0.01 V v e r s u s S H E (8) N O 3 a d - + e - → N O 3 ( a d ) 2 - ; E 0 = - 0.89 V v e r s u s S H E (9) N O 3 ( a d ) 2 - + H 2 O → N O 2 · a d + 2 O H - ; k = 5.5 × 10 4 s - 1 (10) N O 2 · a d + e - → N O 2 ( a d ) - + 2 H 2 O ; E 0 = 1.04 V v e r s u s S H E 2.3 Electrochemical reduction of nitrite to ammonia NO2 − (ad) is the first stable intermediate produced during the reduction of NO3 −. Adsorbed NO2 − (ad) can be further reduced to NO(ad) through electron transfer, as outlined in Eqs. (11) and (12). NO(ad) is considered the key intermediate that governs the selectivity of subsequent reaction pathways [57,58]. As illustrated in Fig. 3, the electrochemical reduction of NO(ad) determines the selectivity of the NO3 − reduction reaction, potentially leading to the formation of either NH3 (NH4 +) or N2. Ammonia, as one of the final products of nitrite electroreduction, has garnered extensive attention due to its pivotal role in chemical engineering and agriculture, and it is also the main focus of this review. (11) N O 2 ( a d ) - + e - → N O 2 ( a d ) 2 - ; E 0 = - 0.47 V v e r s u s S H E (12) N O 2 ( a d ) 2 - + H 2 O → N O ( a d ) + 2 O H - NO(ad) can be converted to NH3 through two distinct pathways. One pathway is the reduction of NO(ad) to NH3 via stepwise protonation and hydrogenation (Eqs. (13)–(16)). This pathway predominantly yields NH3 due to the kinetically favorable formation of N–H bonds mediated by hydrogen compared to N–N bonds, making NH3 the primary product of this process [59,60]. (13) N O ( a d ) + 2 H ( a d ) → N ( a d ) + H 2 (14) N a d + H ( a d ) → N H a d (15) N H ( a d ) + H ( a d ) → N H 2 ( a d ) (16) N H 2 ( a d ) + H ( a d ) → N H 3 a d Another common mechanism for NH3 evolution involves the electrochemical reduction of NO(ad) to NH3 via a series of sequential direct charge transfer reactions (Eqs. (17)–(20)) [61]. This electroche Vooys-Koper-Chumanovmical–electrochemical (EE) mechanism is widely regarded as the most accepted pathway for NO(ad) reduction [62,63]. In this pathway, the reduction of HNO(ad) to H2NO(ad) via Eq. (18) is considered the rate-determining step [64]. This is followed by a rapid charge transfer step (Eq. (19)), which converts the unstable H2NO(ad) into hydroxylamine (H2NOH) [65]. Hydroxylamine is often identified as a byproduct of NO3 − reduction reaction, which further supports the EE mechanism for ammonia formation [66,67]. The equilibrium between NH3 and NH4 + in solution strongly depends on the pH. At a high pH, ammonium rapidly converts to ammonia, whereas nitrogen is more stable in the form of ammonium at a lower pH [68]. (17) N O ( a d ) + H + + e - ↔ H N O a d ; E 0 = - 0.78 V v e r s u s S H E (18) H N O ( a d ) + H + + e - → H 2 N O ( a d ) ; E 0 = 0.52 V v e r s u s S H E (19) H 2 N O ( a d ) + H + + e - → H 2 N O H ; E 0 = 0.90 V v e r s u s S H E (20) H 2 N O H + 2 H + + 2 e - → N H 3 + H 2 O ; E 0 = 0.42 V v e r s u s S H E 2.4 Other reactions The NRA is a highly complex process involving multiple intermediates and reaction pathways, leading to the generation of various by-products [69]. For instance, N2, as one of the main products of nitrate reduction, is also one of the most competitive by-products in the electrocatalytic NRA process. Notably, N2 can be produced via at least three pathways, and its formation is thermodynamically favorable [70]. One pathway involves the reduction of H2NOH, a minor intermediate that may accumulate during the electrochemical reduction of NO(ad) to NH3. This intermediate can subsequently be reduced to N2, as described in Eq. (21) [64]. The other two pathways for N2 formation follow the Vooys-Koper-Chumanov mechanism [65,71,72] and the Duca-Feliu-Koper mechanism, respectively. In the Duca-Feliu-Koper mechanism, NO(ad) reacts with the intermediate ammonia species (NH2) to form NONH2(ad), which can then rapidly decompose into N2, as described in Eqs. (22) and (23). In contrast, the Vooys-Koper-Chumanov mechanism typically occurs under acidic conditions, where NO(ad) reacts electrochemically with NO(aq), producing the short-lived byproduct NO dimer (HN2O2) (Eq. (24)) [73–75]. (21) H 2 N O H + H N O → N 2 + H 2 O (22) N O ( a d ) + N H 2 ( a d ) → N O N H 2 ( a d ) (23) N O N H 2 ( a d ) → N 2 + H 2 O (24) N O ( a d ) + N O ( a q ) + H + + e - → H N 2 O 2 ; E 0 = 0.0 V v e r s u s S H E (25) H N 2 O 2 ( a d ) + H + + e - → N 2 O ( a d ) + H 2 O ; E 0 = 1.59 V v e r s u s S H E (26) N 2 O ( a d ) + 2 H + + 2 e - → N 2 + H 2 O Reactions involving NO2 − (ad) may also result in the formation of byproducts, particularly under highly acidic conditions and elevated nitrate reactant concentrations (1.0–4.0 M). In such environments, NO2 − may convert into weak nitrous acid (HNO2), which can initiate autocatalytic reactions [76]. In the catalytic cycle, different initiators may lead to two self-catalytic mechanisms: the Vetter mechanism [77] or the Schmid mechanism [78–80]. In the Vetter mechanism, under strongly acidic conditions (pKa = 3.4), NO2 − (ad) is protonated to form HNO2. Subsequently, HNO2 reacts with NO3 − to produce dinitrogen tetroxide (N2O4), which rapidly decomposes into two nitrogen dioxide (NO2) molecules, as described in Eqs. (27)–(29) [38]. In the Schmid mechanism, HNO2 undergoes deprotonation in a highly acidic electrolyte environment to form the nitrosonium ion (NO+) (Eq. (30)). Within the autocatalytic cycle, NO+ is converted into an electroactive species that captures electrons to produce NO (Eq. (31)) [81]. The NO subsequently reacts with N2O4 generated in Eq. (28) to regenerate HNO2 (Eq. (32)). By controlling the reaction conditions and selecting appropriate electrode materials and catalysts, selective reduction of nitrates can be achieved [82,83]. In the electrocatalytic NRA process, the potential required for the reduction of NO3 − to NH3 is typically more negative than that for the HER, which can lead to the concurrent occurrence of HER. Furthermore, the kinetic process of the NRA reaction is more complex than that of the HER, adding to the difficulty in achieving high selectivity and efficiency. Recent studies have reported that the starting potential for ammonia synthesis in industrial applications is + 0.22 V vs. RHE [85]. However, under alkaline conditions (pH = 14), the theoretical starting potential for NRA is + 0.69 V, which is significantly higher than the currently reported optimal starting potential [34]. A higher overpotential not only results in energy losses but also facilitates the occurrence of HER. Consequently, related studies focus on reducing the optimal reaction potential for NRA and suppressing HER through the design of catalysts and other strategies [84,86,87]. At this stage, NO2 − is the primary byproduct of the NRA reaction. When optimizing electrocatalytic conditions, it is crucial to balance reducing overpotential with controlling byproduct formation to achieve efficient and selective NH3 synthesis. To a certain extent, the presence of H can promote the hydrogenation of NO during the electrocatalytic NRA reaction, favoring the formation of N–H bonds and enhancing the selective synthesis of NH3 [88,89]. The HER involves electrochemical hydrogen adsorption (Volmer reaction), electrochemical desorption (Heyrovsky reaction) and chemical desorption (Tafel reaction) (Eqs. (33)–(35)) [90]. By analyzing the overpotentials using Tafel polarization and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) data, kinetic parameters for HER can be determined. Typically, the system exhibits two time constants: one associated with the charging and discharging of the double layer, and the other related to the adsorption and desorption of hydrogen, following the Volmer-Heyrovsky-Tafel mechanism. In systems where the second time constant is not resolvable, the HER follows the Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism [91]. The H(ad) produced in the Volmer process can directly promote the hydrogenation of NO through Eqs. (13)–(16), thereby facilitating the synthesis of NH3. However, some electron donors are undesirably consumed via the Heyrovsky pathway, leading to an unsatisfactory FE and ammonia yield in the NRA reaction [92,93]. As the HER progresses, H+ ions in the electrolyte are consumed, which not only reduces the concentration of proton donors in the electrolyte but also negatively impacts the NO reduction reaction for ammonia synthesis (Eqs. (17)–(20)). Insufficient proton transfer may also shift the reaction pathway, increasing the byproduct formation and significantly reducing reaction efficiency. Consequently, the performance of the electrocatalytic NRA reaction is often suboptimal due to the competing effects of HER [42,94]. The H2 adsorbed on the electrode surface may interfere with NO3 − adsorption and reduction, further compromising NRA performance. Therefore, the hydrogen content must be carefully balanced between HER and NRA to optimize FE and selectivity for NH3/NH4 + [58]. Electrocatalysts with rapid HER kinetics may suppress NO3 − reduction, as NRA typically occurs at potentials below those required for HER [95]. In such cases, developing catalysts that effectively promote NRA while suppressing HER is essential for optimizing the electrochemical process and improving energy utilization efficiency [96–98]. Additionally, the production of N2, which requires three fewer electrons than NH3 synthesis, is one of the main side reactions in the electrocatalytic NRA process. N2 formation is influenced by factors, including the catalyst composition, reaction potential, and electrolyte environment, all of which can direct electrons toward the N2 production pathway. For instance, Pt (100) shows significant differences in product selectivity across different reaction media: alkaline media favor N2 generation, whereas acidic media preferentially promote NH3 production [67,99]. Unlike the NH3 production pathway, N2 formation involves N–N bond formation, a second-order reaction that competes with the first-order NH3 production pathway, often reducing NH3 selectivity. Furthermore, N2O, as a key reaction intermediate, is typically a prerequisite for N2 generation [100]. The combined effect of these factors makes N2 production a significantly competitive reaction, further complicating the selective generation of NH3 under certain conditions. (33) H 2 O + e - → H ( a d ) + O H - (34) H 2 O + H ( a d ) + e - ↔ H 2 + O H - (35) H ( a d ) + H ( a d ) → H 2 In this section, we will examine the key factors influencing the performance and selectivity of electrochemical NRA reactions. This includes analyzing the impact of electrolyte properties, reduction potential, the working electrode, and electrolytic cell design (Fig. 4 ). The goal is to enhance both the overall reaction efficiency and product selectivity through the optimization of these conditions. 3.2 Effect of electrolyte properties 3.2.1 pH of the electrolyte The electrochemical NRA can operate over a wide pH range, with studies investigating conditions from highly acidic [101,102] to highly alkaline [99,103,104] environments. However, during ammonia synthesis in NRA, the local pH of the electrolyte will vary during the electrocatalytic process, leading to changes in the catalyst's surface microenvironment. These variations can influence the reaction pathway and selectivity of the catalytic process [105]. As electrode reactions proceed, the pH of the electrolyte near the cathode will gradually increase due to the formation of OH−, while the pH near the anode will decrease due to the accumulation of H+ [106,107]. This pH change not only affects the overall equilibrium of the reaction, but may also affect the proton-electron coupling transfer kinetics, further regulating the selectivity and efficiency of the process. Clark et al. investigated the effect of pH on the NO2 − reduction performance of aluminum-supported Rh surface and found that pH value can significantly influence the selectivity of ammonia synthesis (Fig. 5 a) [108]. The experimental results showed that when the solution pH was 11.5, ammonia selectivity reached as high as 95%, whereas at low pH conditions, ammonia selectivity was nearly 0 (Fig. 5b). This discrepancy is attributed to the poisoning of Rh by NO adsorbed on its surface at low pH, while adjusting the pH can suppress the formation of NO. Thus, pH significantly affects the selectivity for NH3/NH4 +, with high pH conditions being more favorable for the reduction of NO2 − to NH3/NH4 + on Rh. The pH of the electrolyte also directly influences the proton-electron coupling transfer process. In acidic environments, the current density is two orders of magnitude higher than that in alkaline electrolyte solutions [109]. Proton availability primarily governs reaction kinetics in acidic conditions, with pH increasing as protons are consumed during the reaction. Conversely, in alkaline electrolytes, lower proton concentrations mean that water transport governs the current density [110]. At the same time, the NRA system generates OH−, which increases the alkalinity of the electrolyte. Using a buffered electrolyte can effectively mitigate significant pH fluctuations, maintaining a stable pH environment during the NRA process. The buffering capacity of the electrolyte may influence the types of surface reactants and the balance of the catalyst surface microenvironment, thereby regulating the performance of the NRA [111]. Under different pH conditions, the surface of metal electrodes is often covered by different substances due to the varying active species present in the solution [112]. The pH of the solution affects the reaction process, the formation of intermediates, and the solubility of the products [113,114]. Elena et al. studied the reduction of nitrate on a copper single-crystal surface in both acidic and alkaline solutions using electrochemical methods coupled with in situ characterization techniques (Fig. 5c, d) [66]. Analytical techniques indicate a diverse product distribution in two different electrolytes. In acidic media, the Cu electrode exhibits the ability to form NO and ammonia, while in alkaline media, Cu reduces NO3 − to NO2 −, which is further converted into hydroxylamine. In addition, the solution pH also significantly influences the oxidation pathway of NH3/NH4 +. In alkaline solutions, NH3, after being adsorbed onto the anode, is primarily oxidized to N2 through direct electrolysis. In contrast, in neutral and acidic solutions, NH4 + is indirectly oxidized to N2 indirectly through interactions with OH radicals generated during oxygen evolution, rather than via direct electrolysis, which significantly reduces the rate of ammonia decomposition. As the electrolysis reaction proceeds, the pH of the electrolyte near the cathode gradually increases due to the formation of OH−, while the pH of the electrolyte near the anode gradually decreases due to the accumulation of H+ [106,107]. Consequently, the electrochemical reduction of nitrate primarily occurs under alkaline conditions. Additionally, the difference in pH also affects the oxidation pathways of NH3/NH4 +. In alkaline solutions, NH3 is adsorbed onto the anode and is predominantly oxidized to N2 through direct electrolysis. In contrast, in neutral and acidic solutions, NH4 + is indirectly oxidized to N2 by OH radicals generated under oxygen evolution conditions, rather than by direct electrolysis, which leads to a significant reduction in the rate of ammonia decomposition [115]. In summary, although changing the initial pH has little effect on the kinetics and efficiency of nitrate reduction [116,117], adjusting the pH to enhance the catalytic selectivity for ammonia synthesis is a possible approach [107]. Regardless of the electrolyte being acidic or alkaline, pH fluctuations are inevitable during the NRA process. However, systematic studies on the effect of pH in NRA remain relatively limited, highlighting a critical area for further research. 3.2.2 Initial NO3 − concentration Mechanistic studies of electrochemical NRA have revealed that the diffusion, adsorption, and chemical reactions of NO3 − with intermediates are largely influenced by the initial NO3 − concentration in the electrolyte [118,119]. At low NO3 − concentrations, the mass transfer of NO3 − to the catalyst surface limits the rate of the NRA reaction. Conversely, at higher nitrate concentrations, the reduction efficiency is primarily influenced by the availability and activity of the active sites on the catalyst surface [37]. However, excessive NO3 − concentrations may induce surface coverage effects on the catalyst, which can suppress certain reaction steps or lead to changes in the catalyst surface structure. Dima et al. investigated the reaction kinetics of NO3 − on polycrystalline Pt electrodes. In a 0.5 M H2SO4 solution, when the surface coverage of NO3 − on the polycrystalline Pt electrode was low, the reaction order at 0.142 V vs. RHE was observed to be 0.51 [120]. In HClO4 solution with NO3 − concentrations exceeding 0.1 M, studies have shown that the reaction order on the polycrystalline Pt electrode is negatively correlated with the NO3 − concentration [76]. It is believed that the excess NO3 − blocks the catalytic sites, preventing the hydrogen or intermediates required for the NO3 − reduction reaction from being available on the catalyst surface, thereby reducing the reaction rate. Therefore, understanding the multifaceted impact of NO3 − concentration on the NRA reaction mechanism is crucial for optimizing catalyst design and improving reaction selectivity. Under the same conditions, the higher the initial NO3 − concentration in the solution, the lower the NO3 − removal efficiency. Tao et al. investigated the effect of initial NO3 − concentrations ranging from 20 to 500 mg L−1 on the nitrate conversion ability and ammonia selectivity of Ni3Co6S8 nanospheres with sulfur-rich vacancies (NCS-2) (Fig. 6 a) [121]. When the NO3 − concentration was less than 200 mg L−1, the NO3 − conversion rate and NH3 selectivity of NCS-2 both exceeded 90%. With increasing concentrations of initial NO3 −, the NO3 − conversion and NH3 selectivity decreased. Wang et al. found that the efficiency of electrocatalytic NO3 − removal using Co3O4/Ti cathode was affected by the initial NO3 − concentration, which also influenced the formation of reduction products (Fig. 6b) [122]. At initial NO3 − concentrations of < 100 mg L−1, the removal efficiency of the system was close to 100%; the main reduction products were NH4 + (∼60%) and N2. When the initial NO3 − concentration reached 200 mg L−1, the NO3 − removal efficiency decreased to 58%, while NH4 + generation efficiency increased to ∼79%. Su et al. also experimentally demonstrated that as the initial NO3 − concentration increased, the NO3 − removal efficiency decreased, while NH3 production increased (Fig. 6c) [123]. Wu et al. studied electrocatalytic NRA in nitrate solutions with higher initial concentrations (2000–6000 mg L−1) (Fig. 6d) [124]. At NO3 − concentrations > 4000 mg L−1, an FE of nearly 80% was achieved, and with increasing NO3 − concentration, the ammonia yield also showed an upward trend. The conversion of high concentrations of NO3 − to NH4 + indicates the feasibility of electrocatalytic nitrate reduction at high nitrate concentrations. Additionally, higher initial NO3 − concentrations can suppress the HER, reducing its charge consumption on the electrode. However, whether in a single-chamber or dual-chamber cell, under otherwise unchanged conditions, the absolute amount of nitrate removed increases with rising nitrate concentration, which means that more electrical energy can be utilized for the electrocatalytic reduction of NO3 − [52]. To facilitate the industrial application of electrocatalytic NO3 − wastewater treatment technology, numerous studies have been conducted in this field. NO3 − wastewater typically has a more complex composition, presenting several challenges in the treatment process. Zheng et al. treated high-concentration wastewater samples containing 2552 ± 38 mg L−1 NO3 −-N and conducted pilot-scale experiments, achieving a 95.3% conversion rate of NO3 − and a 95.5% selectivity [41]. This study not only demonstrated excellent electrocatalytic performance in treating high-concentration NO3 − wastewater but also provided an effective technological pathway for addressing complex pollutant treatment and wastewater resource recovery. Miller et al. treated urban secondary effluent containing 120 mg L−1 NO3 −-N and innovatively designed a novel reaction-separation process: Electrocatalyst-in-a-box (ECaB) [125]. The process demonstrated the lowest known energy consumption (90.0 ± 2.7 kW h kgN −1) in ammonia production from purified wastewater. Through cost assessments and scenario analysis, the performance gap between the subunit engineering of the ECaB system and its operational system was quantified. The study identified that anode cost and current efficiency are key factors limiting the target total ammonia nitrogen current density. With targeted technological improvements, the total ammonia nitrogen current density is expected to be reduced to 1/2.46 of the experimental value, while simultaneously increasing the NH3 production rate by 20.4 times. With ongoing technological innovation and gradual cost reductions, electrocatalytic NO3 − wastewater treatment technology is anticipated to see widespread application in industrial wastewater purification, water resource recovery, and environmental remediation, thus promoting the adoption and application of green, environmentally friendly technologies. 3.2.3 Coexisting ions In addition to NO3 −, other coexisting ions in the electrolyte can significantly affect the nitrate reduction rate. Therefore, it is necessary to investigate the roles of different ions in the nitrate reduction process. Increasing the concentration of certain anions in the electrolyte can slow the electrocatalytic reduction of nitrate by competing for surface adsorption sites or influencing the magnitude of electrostatic hindering effects. Zhou et al. studied the impact of different concentrations of CO3 2−, PO4 3−, and SO4 2− on nitrate removal efficiency (Fig. 7 a) and found that coexisting anions inhibit nitrate adsorption in the order of CO3 2−>PO4 3−>SO4 2− [126]. Furthermore, the nitrate removal efficiency decreased significantly as the concentration of coexisting anions increased. Huang et al. reached similar conclusions in their study on the effects of coexisting anions such as Cl−, HCO3 −, CO3 2−, and SO4 2− on the efficiency of electrochemical nitrate reduction [127]. As shown in Fig. 7b, the inhibitory effects of these anions on NO3 − reduction are ranked as follows: Cl− > HCO3 − ≈ CO3 2− > SO4 2−. The migration of these anions toward the cathode surface can be explained by the structure of the electric double layer [128]. During the electrolysis process, due to the opposing effects of charge and electric field, a cation layer preferentially forms on the cathode surface. Subsequently, the anions gradually migrate towards the cation layer under electrostatic attraction, forming the diffusion layer. The inhibition of NO3 − reduction by Cl− may be related to their competitive adsorption in the double layer. The association constants of Na+ with NO3 − and Cl− in the electrolyte are 1.43 and 0.93, respectively. This competitive adsorption decreases the reduction rate of NO3 −. For HCO3 − and CO3 2−, the reasons for their inhibition of NO3 − reduction may involve two aspects. On the one hand, as the solution becomes alkaline during the electrolysis process, HCO3 − is converted into CO3 2−, which may combine with Ca2+ in the solution to form CaCO3 precipitates. These precipitates could deposit on the electrode surface, reducing the active surface area of the electrode. On the other hand, HCO3 − and CO3 2− may influence the reduction of NO3 − by affecting the potential requirements during the electrolysis process. However, in some cases, the inhibitory effect of HCO3 − and CO3 2− on NO3 − reduction may not be significant and could even be offset by the promoting effect of cations. The inhibitory effect of SO4 2− on NO3 − reduction is relatively weak, possibly due to its minimal impact on the electrolyte voltage and the electrode surface. The effect of alkaline cations on the nitrate reduction process is mainly reflected in two aspects. First, as cation donors, metal ions can provide the necessary protons for nitrate reduction through hydrolysis near the electrode surface [51]. Arturo et al. conducted electrocatalytic nitrate reduction tests in electrolytes containing K+ and Na+ cations using real-time on-line differential electrochemical mass spectrometry coupled with chronoamperometry on boron-doped diamond (BDD) electrodes [129]. It was found, via steady-state voltammetry, that the presence of K+ can moderately promote the HER, which favors the reaction between NO3 − and H2. However, in electrolyte solutions containing Na+, stronger HER kinetics lead to the inhibition of N2 formation, as shown in Fig. 7c. Furthermore, the study also found that in solutions containing K+, the selectivity of NO3 − reduction to N2 is higher. This may be due to the more pronounced promoting effect of K+ on the multi-electron transfer steps during the NO3 − reduction process. K+ and Na+ regulate the adsorption and reduction kinetics of NO3 − on the electrode by influencing the charge distribution and electric field strength on the electrode surface. Specifically, these cations appear to modulate the discharge behavior of protons on the BDD electrode surface, a factor that plays a critical role in the efficiency of NO3 − reduction and the selectivity of the products. Second, cations help suppress the electrostatic repulsion between the cathode and nitrate by providing balanced positive charge centers and forming neutral ions [38]. Katsounaros et al. showed that the presence of different alkali metal electrolytes can accelerate the electrochemical reduction of nitrate, in the order of Li+<Na+<K+<Cs+ [51]. This is the result of the combined effects of the ionic radius, charge density, and the interaction strength between the cation and NO3 −. As the ionic radius of the cation increases, the charge density decreases. A larger ionic radius and smaller charge density lead to the formation of a more diffuse double layer on the electrode surface, which facilitates the approach and adsorption of NO3 −, thereby promoting its reduction. In addition, the properties and concentration of alkali metals can regulate the activity of protons on the electrode surface, affecting the proton discharge rate and reduction pathway, thus promoting multi-electron transfer and enabling more efficient reduction of NO3 −. When the electrolyte contains multivalent cations such as Ca2+ and La3+, a higher reduction rate is achieved compared to alkali metals. These cations have higher charge densities and more complex electronic structures, allowing them to form more stable ion pairs with NO3 −. The formation of ion pairs may reduce the direct interaction between NO3 − and the electrode surface, while also indirectly promoting the reduction of NO3 − by modulating proton discharge behavior and electron transfer. In short, anions primarily influence the NRA process by regulating the number of active sites and the buffering effect of the local pH [88,130]. In the double layer, the role of cations is more complex. They can affect the electrostatic interactions between NO3 − and the cathode, the stability of reaction intermediates, as well as the ionization activity of water [131]. Therefore, a comprehensive evaluation of the electrocatalytic NRA performance needs to fully consider the impact of coexisting ions. 3.3 Impact of applied potential The effect of applied potential on the electrocatalytic NRA can be analyzed from both thermodynamic and kinetic perspectives. From a thermodynamic standpoint, changes in voltage directly affect ΔG of the reaction. As the potential increases, the free energy of the reaction may decrease, promoting the electrocatalytic reduction of NO3 −. However, if the voltage becomes too high, the reaction's free energy may increase significantly, leading to the occurrence of side reactions (such as the HER), which would reduce the selectivity for NH3 synthesis. Furthermore, changes in voltage also influence the electronic structure of the electrode surface and its adsorption properties toward the reactants. The adsorption of NO3 − on the electrode surface typically shows a negative ΔG, indicating the feasibility and spontaneity of the adsorption process [132]. However, the NRA process is still influenced by the slow *H transfer kinetics and unfavorable thermodynamics [133]. Properly increasing the applied voltage can promote an increase in current density, enhance the adsorption of NO3 − and *H on the electrode surface, and accelerate the progression of the reaction. Selective reduction of NO3 − can be achieved by controlling the cathode potential during the electrolysis reaction [134–136]. Qin et al. synthesized metal (Ru/Co/Ni)-doped Cu electrodes for electrocatalytic synthesis of NH4 + at room temperature [137]. They studied the selectivity of NO3 − electrocatalytic products on Ru-Ni CF and Ru-Co CF electrodes in the voltage range of −1.6 to −2.0 V (versus Ag/AgCl), and found that as the voltage increased, the selectivity for NH4 + increased. Shih et al. also reached a similar conclusion in their study on the effect of overpotential on the electrocatalytic reduction of NO3 − using Cu/Ni composite electrodes (Fig. 8 a) [138]. At low electrode potential (−0.6 V versus Hg/HgO), NO3 − was preferentially converted to N2 with a selection rate of 55.6%. However, as the electrode potential increased, the dominance of N2 decreased, and the concentration of NH4 + increased significantly. At high electrode potential (−1.2 V versus Hg/HgO), NH4 + became the main product of the electrolysis reaction with a selection rate of 89.1%. The operating potential and current density critically influence the electrochemical reduction kinetics of NO3 −. Within the designated potential range, an increase in current density enhances the electrokinetic effects on the electrode surface, thereby accelerating the reduction rate of NO3 −. In their study, Hong et al. employed a composite anode material, nZVI/RuO2–IrO2/Ti, to examine the impact of applied voltage on the elimination of NO3 − [139]. As demonstrated in Fig. 8b, an increase in applied voltage results in a higher current density, which accelerates the reduction rate of NO3 −. Within 30 min of electrolysis, at an applied voltage of 1.2 V, the residual concentration of NO3 − slightly decreased to 92 mg L−1 from an initial value of 100 mg L−1. In contrast, at 10.0 V, the residual concentration rapidly diminished to 55 mg L−1. Wu et al. investigated the effect of working potential on the conversion of NO3 − using bimetallic electrodes Cu/Ni and Rh0.2Cu0.8/Ni [140]. The experimental results indicate that working potential is a critical factor in controlling NO3 − conversion rate, ammonia selectivity, and yield (Fig. 8c). Fang et al. have demonstrated a strong correlation between the electrode potential and the yield of ammonia, noting that an increase in the applied voltage substantially enhances the efficiency of synthesizing ammonia [141]. Compared to constant potential conditions, pulsed electrolysis technology offers distinct advantages in local microenvironments that cannot be achieved under conventional constant potential or constant current conditions, making it an effective strategy for enhancing NH3 yield FE [142]. Pulsed electrolysis, which applies periodically varying potential and current, has been widely utilized for the production of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) [143], Organic electrosynthesis [144] and CO2 reduction, among other fields [145]. To overcome the issues of limited NO3 − distribution near the working electrode and slow kinetics caused by competitive side reactions during the conversion of low-concentration NO3 − to NH3 at excessively low potentials, Huang et al. proposed an optimized pulsed potential sequence and selected a carbon-supported RuIn3 intermetallic compound (RuIn3/C) as the model catalyst for the pulsed electro reduction of low-concentration NO3 − to NH3 [146]. Under pulsed conditions, RuIn3/C achieved an FE of up to 97.6% and an NH3 production rate of 2.7 mmol h−1 mgRu −1, significantly higher than those observed under constant potential conditions (FE: 65.8%, NH3 production rate: 1.1 mmol h−1 mgRu −1). Mass transfer analysis and in situ intermediate characterization results demonstrate that pulsed electrolysis can promote the accumulation of NO3 − near the electrode (Fig. 9 a) and facilitate the formation of more active *NO intermediates with a top adsorption configuration, thereby synergistically enhancing the reduction of low-concentration NO3 −. Similarly, Boppella et al. applied pulsed electrolysis technology to the electrocatalytic NRA reaction, effectively overcoming mass transfer limitations at low NO3 − concentrations and suppressing the competitive HER [147]. In a 0.5 M NO3 − electrolyte, the Cu1Ru10 alloy catalyst achieved an impressive 94.6% NH3 Faradaic efficiency. Compared to constant potential conditions, the NH3 production rate significantly increased by approximately 3.75 times (Fig. 9b). The Cu/Cu2O heterojunction has been shown to effectively promote the conversion of NO3 − to NO2 −, enabling efficient NH3 synthesis. However, its electrochemical reconstruction process is unstable. To address this, Bu et al. proposed an in situ electrochemical peroxide strategy via pulsed electrolysis, achieving in situ electrochemical peroxide formation and self-repair of Cu/Cu2O in electrocatalytic NRA [148]. During the oxidation pulse, Cu is oxidized to CuO and is regenerated to Cu/Cu2O during the reduction process. The tandem catalytic strategy, further optimized by Ni alloying to modulate H adsorption, balances the reaction rates of NO3 − to NO2 − and NO2 − to NH3, significantly enhancing the efficiency of NH3 synthesis at relatively low overpotentials (Fig. 9c). Under optimal pulsed conditions, the electro-pulse-driven Cu-Ni tandem catalyst exhibited an NH3 Faradaic efficiency of 88.0% ± 1.6% and an NH3 production rate of 583.6 ± 2.4 μmol cm−2 h−1. This study provides direct theoretical guidance for achieving stable tandem active sites through pulsed electrolysis. Li et al. developed a synergistic strategy combining pulsed electrolysis with Cu single-atom gel (Cu SAGs) catalysts, which effectively regulates detrimental intermediate byproducts through tandem catalysis, enabling efficient conversion of NO3 − to NH3 [149]. The study systematically analyzed the effects of constant potential (Fig. 9d) and pulsed potential (Fig. 9e) on the electrocatalytic reduction performance of NO3 − and the reaction pathways. Mechanistic studies suggest that the 3D channel structure of Cu SAGs and its high selectivity for NO2 − reduction allow NO2 − intermediates to locally accumulate at lower pulsed potentials, effectively suppressing the occurrence of HER. Further energy analysis indicates that, compared to constant potential electrolysis, the pulsed electrolysis strategy can save approximately 22% of energy, while the yield increases by about 28%, demonstrating its potential feasibility for practical application. In conclusion, working potential is one of the key factors influencing the NO3 − reduction process. According to reaction mechanism analysis, the higher the applied voltage and current density, the faster the reduction rate of NO3 − and the greater the selectivity for NH3 synthesis. However, excessive overpotential may trigger multiple side reactions, leading to the generation of corrosive gases, which can accelerate electrode corrosion and limit energy utilization efficiency [150,151]. Compared to constant potential electrolysis, pulsed electrolysis effectively alleviates mass transfer limitations through dynamic potential control and significantly suppresses the occurrence of HER, thereby enhancing the efficiency of the target reaction. Especially in low NO3 − concentration environments, pulsed electrolysis demonstrates higher conversion rates and selectivity for NO3 − to NH3. 3.4 Effect of working electrode During the electrocatalytic NRA process, both the electrolyte and the electrode play critical roles in the current cycling. Based on the material composition and structural morphology, electrodes used for electrocatalytic NRA can be classified into glassy carbon electrodes, rotating disk electrodes, porous electrodes, and self-supported electrodes. Glassy carbon electrodes, known for their good conductivity, are commonly used in electrochemical analysis. However, in the electrochemical NRA reaction, traditional glassy carbon electrodes, while effective in reducing NO3 −, suffer from limited durability. Kuramochi et al. evaluated the performance of glassy carbon electrodes in electrocatalytic NRA [152]. Surprisingly, the glassy carbon electrode achieved a 92% NH3 Faradaic efficiency and an NH3 production rate of 24 µmol h−1 cm−2. However, subsequent stability tests revealed an unfavorable trend. As the reaction time was extended, the NH3 selectivity of the electrode decreased, and after 30 h of electrolysis, the NH3 FE dropped to 40%. This phenomenon can be attributed to the hindered diffusion of NO3 − within the pores of the glassy carbon material, causing the reaction selectivity to shift towards HER. Therefore, it is necessary to modify the surface of the glassy carbon electrode to enhance its adsorption capacity for NO3 − and long-term stability. Chebotareva et al. surface-modified glassy carbon electrodes with phthalocyanine complexes of Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn (MPc) and investigated the electrocatalytic reduction of NO3 − on the modified electrodes in alkaline solutions [153]. Experimental results showed that the glassy carbon electrode modified with MPc significantly lowered the overpotential for NO3 − reduction, with NH3 as the primary reduction product. The rotating disk electrode (RCE), known for its excellent mass transfer characteristics, achieves a turbulent flow at low rotation speeds and exhibits uniform current and potential distribution, making it widely used in various interdisciplinary fields [154]. Pérez et al. investigated the performance of a batch electrochemical reactor equipped with a copper-based RCE for the cathodic activation in the removal of NO3 − [155]. Under constant potential conditions, the electrode was used to treat a solution with a pH of 5.6 and a NO3 − concentration of 30 mM. After 1 h of reaction at −1.2 V vs. SCE, the NO3 − conversion rate reached 92%, with a molar yield of 86% for NH3. In addition, Oriol et al. used an economical batch system with a Fe-based RCE as the cathode and Ti|IrO2 as the anode to treat 400 mL of 10 mM NO3 − solution at pH 6.5, achieving complete NO3 − removal at −1.8 V vs. Hg|Hg2SO4 [156]. These studies demonstrate the excellent performance of RCEs in NO3 − reduction reactions. Porous electrode materials, due to their unique structure, often exhibit high specific surface areas, which increase the number of active sites. In electrocatalysis, metal foam materials, as representative porous electrodes, have attracted significant attention. Xue et al. introduced a direct boronization treatment strategy for nickel foam to fabricate high-performance electrodes with abundant surface electrons [157]. This microfabrication process converts the nickel oxide on the surface of nickel foam into a binary nanostructure composed of metallic nickel and amorphous nickel borate, effectively lowering the work function of the foam. In this structure, the abundant electrons on the high specific surface area of Ni can efficiently capture and reduce NO3 −, enabling highly selective NH3 synthesis. Additionally, Krzywda et al. explored a novel approach for electrochemical NO3 − reduction using Ti-based hollow fiber electrodes in acidic electrolytes [158]. In this system, when a gas flow containing reactants was introduced, the reactants in the aqueous solution were effectively delivered to the electrode surface. By introducing an inert gas flow into the porous walls of the hollow fiber electrode, the mass transfer efficiency near the solid–liquid interface was greatly enhanced, achieving an NH3 current density of approximately −75 mA cm−2, marking a significant improvement in electrocatalytic efficiency. The use of self-supported materials as the carrier for active sites significantly increased the exposed surface area, thereby enhancing the catalyst's practicality and stability [159,160]. This electrode design strategy ensures the efficient utilization of the catalyst during the reaction process, optimizing overall catalytic performance. Liu et al. developed a highly active self-supported catalyst (Cu/PTS) through an anodic oxidation combined with hydrothermal/pyrolysis method, successfully embedding Cu species onto a porous titanium substrate [161]. In alkaline media, the Cu/PTS-catalyzed NRA reaction achieves an ammonia production rate of up to 7292.43 µg h−1 cm−2, with an FE close to 100%. This outstanding performance is attributed to the self-supported structure of the porous titanium plate and the embedding of copper species on its surface, which not only provides excellent electrochemical stability but also enables the efficient reduction of NO3 − in complex aqueous environments. Xiong et al. reported a self-supported electrode (Co-NDC/NF) by anchoring a two-dimensional cobalt-based metal–organic framework (MOF) nanosheet array onto a three-dimensional nickel foam [162]. In the NRA reaction, the electrode demonstrates exceptional performance, achieving a high NH3 production rate of 19200 µg h−1 cm−2 and an NH3 FE of 93.3%, along with excellent electrochemical stability. A flow reactor equipped with a large-area Co-NDC/NF electrode can generate 1096 mg L−1 of NH3 at industrial current densities. The supported electrode, which is formed by coating the catalyst material onto the surface of a support material, is a common type of electrode in electrocatalytic NRA reactions. To ensure the stability of the electrode during operation, support materials with good mechanical properties, conductivity, and chemical stability are typically selected, such as carbon paper, carbon cloth, metals, and metal oxides. According to the Sabatier principle, the adsorption strength of the reactants on the catalyst surface should be maintained within an optimal range—neither too strong nor too weak—in order to achieve optimal catalytic performance [163]. Previous studies have shown that excessive adsorption of *NO2 on the electrode surface may lead to catalyst poisoning, hindering subsequent reactions. On the other hand, insufficient adsorption can cause significant desorption of *NO2, leading to the accumulation of NO2 −, which in turn is detrimental to the subsequent hydrogenation process [164]. In addition, the adsorption configuration and reaction pathway of *NO can also have a significant impact on the deoxygenation and hydrogenation steps [165]. To regulate the adsorption properties of nitrogen oxides on the electrode surface, Wu et al. proposed a catalyst design strategy aimed at modulating the adsorption strength and configuration of the intermediates [166]. By manipulating the catalyst structure and adjusting the adsorption configuration of intermediates, artificial regulation of the product distribution was achieved, significantly lowering the reaction energy barrier. Building on this, a series of Zn-doped Cu nanosheet catalysts were synthesized experimentally and loaded onto carbon paper to form the electrodes. Zn doping imparts the catalyst with a moderate adsorption capability for nitrogen-containing species (*NO3 and *NO2), enhancing the conversion rate of NO2 − while simultaneously reducing the HER activity. In situ spectroscopic analysis and theoretical calculations indicate that the bridge-type adsorption of the key intermediate *NO weakens the N–O bond, thereby lowering the reaction energy barrier and significantly enhancing the activity of NO3 − reduction to NH3. At the same time, Ma et al. conducted an in-depth analysis of the adsorption energies of three key intermediates, *NO3, *NO, and·H2O, and investigated the d-band center characteristics of 21 transition metals (III-V and IB groups) forming intermetallic compounds (IMC) with Sb/Bi as electrocatalysts [167]. The study revealed that the hexagonal CoSb-IMC achieved an optimal balance in the adsorption of these key intermediates, exhibiting outstanding electrocatalytic NRA. Specifically, its FE reached 96.3%, with NH3 selectivity at 89.1%, and it demonstrated excellent stability. The RCE, through the thin-layer diffusion effect generated by rotation, can effectively improve the mass transfer process and enhance the nitrate reduction efficiency. Glassy carbon electrodes exhibit good conductivity, but their mass transfer process is relatively poor, often requiring surface modification strategies to enhance catalytic activity and long-term stability. Porous electrodes and self-supporting electrodes are the two most common electrode configurations in the field of NRA. Porous electrodes, with their distinctive pore structures, significantly enhance the electrode's surface area, thereby increasing the number of active sites, which facilitates the effective adsorption of NO3 −. Similarly, self-supporting electrodes also offer a large specific surface area and abundant active sites. Their three-dimensional structural characteristics not only optimize electron transport pathways but also promote the efficient diffusion of reactants and products, which is essential for effective NO3 − reduction. Supported electrodes, widely used in electrocatalytic NRA reactions, provide high flexibility and tunable catalyst distribution. However, a major issue encountered during long-term operation is the detachment of the catalyst from the surface of support materials, such as carbon paper, which compromises their stability in practical applications. In summary, various electrode types, each with unique structural advantages, hold great potential for improving mass transfer and enhancing catalytic efficiency. The design of electrodes is thus a critical direction for advancing the application of electrocatalytic NO3 − reduction technologies. 3.5 Effect of reactor structure At the laboratory scale, the selectivity of electrocatalytic NRA and the activity of electrocatalysts are usually evaluated in single- or dual-chamber cells containing at least two electrodes. Electrolysis can be conducted in two ways: potentiostatic and galvanostatic. Potentiostatic electrolysis is achieved by applying a fixed and constant potential through an external power supply. Under constant potential conditions, the selectivity of NO3 − reduction can be more effectively controlled. However, to maintain the electrode potential, a three-electrode system consisting of a working electrode, counter electrode, and reference electrode must be employed. For NRA, the working electrode is the cathode where the NO3 − reduction reaction occurs. Reduction and oxidation reactions occur simultaneously on the cathode and anode surfaces of the electrolyzer, respectively [168,169]. Fig. 10 illustrates the structure of the single-chamber and dual-chamber cell setups, as well as the NO3 − reduction process within. 3.5.1 Single-chamber cell The cathode and anode of the single-chamber cell coexist in the same electrolyte environment (Fig. 10a), which creates conditions for rapid and unrestricted electron transfer. Additionally, the lack of an ion-exchange membrane and the short distance between the electrodes make the single-chamber reactor simple in design, economically feasible, and typically exhibit lower internal resistance [170]. For example, in a single-chamber reactor, the electrolytic reaction can reduce nitrate-containing agricultural runoff or industrial wastewater to NH4 +, which can then be converted into ammonium nitrate fertilizer for reuse [171]. Preliminary techno-economic analysis suggests that the initial cost of this strategy is estimated to be lower than the range of industrial ammonium nitrate synthesis costs. Moreover, the oxidants produced by the anode reactions can further purify the water. In a single reaction chamber, paired reactions may favor the removal of NO3 −. Song et al. achieved efficient nitrate removal in an undivided electrochemical reactor (Fig. 11 a) [172]. In the presence of chloride, NO3 − removal efficiency reached up to 89.6%. In a solution containing appropriate Cl−, NO3 − is reduced at the cathode to NH4 +, NO2 −, and N2, while NH4 + and NO2 − are gradually oxidized to N2 and NO3 − by ClO− generated during the electrochlorination process. As N2 is continuously generated and released from the system, nitrogen compounds are gradually degraded with increasing reaction cycles. However, remarkably, in systems containing chloride, the electrochemical reduction of NO3 − in a single-chamber reactor predominantly produces N2 as the main product due to paired reactions, which is not conducive to the selective synthesis of ammonia [172,173]. Furthermore, in such undivided electrochemical reactors, the products of NO3 − reduction at the cathode may be re-oxidized on the anode surface, thereby reducing the overall FE of the electrolytic reaction. Dissolved metal ions generated at the anode may also deposit on the cathode surface, potentially impacting the performance of the original cathode material in electrocatalytic NRA [106]. 3.5.2 Dual-chamber cell A dual-chamber electrochemical reactor separates the anode and cathode into two independent electrode chambers through an ion-exchange membrane, as shown in Fig. 10b, which limits ion transfer between the chambers based on the type of ion-exchange membrane. A cation exchange membrane (e.g., Nafion membrane) is the most commonly used membrane type in electrocatalytic NRA processes, which can block anions from entering the anode chamber from the cathode chamber. In this way, the occurrence of side reactions can be greatly reduced, thereby improving the FE of ammonia synthesis. In addition, due to the physical separation between the two chambers, two different types of wastewater can be treated separately in the cathode and anode chambers, significantly enhancing energy utilization efficiency [170]. Therefore, the dual-chamber cell is more versatile in design and operation. Jiang et al. used the electric explosion method to synthesize three-dimensional porous Cu@Cu2O microspheres (Cu@Cu2O MSs) as electrocatalysts for electrocatalytic NRA and conducted electrochemical experiments in a dual-chamber electrolytic cell [174]. As expected, the system exhibited an ultra-high NH3 yield of 327.6 mmol h−1 g−1 cat (surpassing the Haber-Bosch process with a typical NH3 yield < 200 mmol h−1 g−1 cat), with a maximum FE of 80.57% during electrolysis. Li et al. conducted nitrate reduction experiments in both single-chamber and dual-chamber cells with a cation-exchange membrane [175]. After comparing the results of the two experiments, it was found that the nitrate removal rate of the dual-chamber cell (99.8%) was significantly higher than that in the single-chamber cell (84.3%) in 2.5 h, which is similar to the conclusions obtained from the studies of Ding et al. [169] and Lidia et al. [176]. To overcome the slow kinetics of the oxygen evolution reaction (OER), Xiao et al. designed a formaldehyde oxidation reaction (FOR) using a bipolar membrane reactor, achieving a current density of 300 mA cm−2 at a voltage of 0.81 V vs. RHE. By utilizing Cu2O as a dual-electrode coupled catalyst, they catalyzed both FOR and NO3RR reactions, achieving a high NH3 FE of 99.77% and an ammonia production rate of 1.16 mmol cm−2h−1 at an ultra-low voltage of −0.19 V. This innovative transformation system not only enables the simultaneous treatment of pollutants (HCHO and NO3 −), but also facilitates the synthesis of value-added chemicals (HCOOH and NH3) (Fig. 11b) [177]. However, the dual-chamber reactor also has certain limitations. Since the ion migration between the two chambers must occur through the ion-exchange membrane, this introduces additional resistance, thereby increasing the energy consumption of the electrolytic reaction. Additionally, when the NO3 − concentration in the solution is high, the rapid rise in pH of the catholyte after the reduction of a large amount of NO3 − may affect the lifespan of the cation-exchange membrane in a strongly alkaline environment. Therefore, when the nitrate concentration is higher, factors such as ion exchange membrane and energy consumption need to be taken into account to select a suitable electrolytic cell. In general, the key is how to achieve the greatest balance between efficiency and economy. 3.5.3 Other types of reactors To further improve the ammonia yield and FE of electrocatalytic NRA, new reactor structures have been designed to meet the demands of industrial-scale production. Although most studies have focused on how to prepare more efficient catalysts for nitrate reduction reactions, few have been concerned about how to capture NH3 from the electrolyte. Mi et al. designed a “two-in-one” flow cell electrolyzer by integrating the chambers of nitrate reduction reaction electrolysis and NH3 capture with commercial gas diffusion electrodes to achieve simultaneous NH3 production and capture (Fig. 11c) [178]. Impressively, the rapid separation of the NH3 product promoted the conversion of NO3 − to NH3, achieving an NH3 capture rate of up to 90.4% and a maximum FE for NH3 synthesis of 90.2%. In order to overcome the low solubility of hydrogen in water and enhance the contact between hydrogen and the catalyst surface, catalytic membrane reactors can be considered as an alternative to improve nitrate reduction performance [179–181]. A tubular catalytic reactor with a catalyst membrane is shown in Fig. 11d [182]. This reactor establishes effective contact between different phases (hydrogen, catalyst, and nitrate solution), creating an environment conducive to mass transfer and reaction, playing a key role in promoting the efficient conversion of NO2 −. To fill the gap in large-scale demonstration studies of electrocatalytic NRA, Zheng et al. investigated the application of the self-activated Ni(OH)2@Ni cathode in a custom-designed pilot-scale electrochemical reactor for the treatment of actual industrial wastewater (Fig. 11e), with a focus on evaluating the conversion rate and FE of nitrate reduction to ammonia [41]. Batch-fed and continuous-flow experimental results demonstrated that the pilot-scale cathode exhibited significant advantages in terms of ammonia conversion yield and long-term stability. Chen et al. designed a three-chamber porous solid electrolyte reactor to address the issue of traditional electrocatalytic nitrate reduction's dependence on high-concentration electrolytes (Fig. 11f) [183]. By introducing the treated water from the cathode chamber into the middle porous solid electrolyte layer, a cation shuttling process is established, wherein alkali metal cations cycle from the middle layer back into the cathode chamber. This reactor design significantly enhances the selectivity for nitrate reduction (NO3 −) and effectively suppresses the HER. In wastewater with a nitrate concentration of 2000 ppm, direct reduction of NO3 − using the PSE reactor achieved a high ammonia FE of over 90%, producing NH3 and purified water as the final products. The engineering design of the above-mentioned reactor systems will greatly enhance the efficiency and economic viability of electrocatalytic NRA. Although significant progress has been made in reactor design over the past decade, there remains considerable room for improvement in the future to meet the demand for a wider variety of catalysts, thereby further enhancing the performance of electrocatalytic NRA. This includes, but is not limited to, more optimized reactor structure designs and the implementation of more intelligent operation and control systems. These advancements are expected to elevate the performance of electrocatalytic NRA to new heights, providing more feasible and sustainable solutions for practical applications in environmental management and the energy sector. 3.5.4 Strategic design for the optimization of electrochemical reactors Experimental studies have shown that optimizing the design of electrocatalytic NRA reactors is pivotal for improving reaction efficiency and facilitating their industrial scalability. In laboratory experiments, researchers commonly utilize single-chamber or dual-chamber cells to evaluate the activity and selectivity of electrocatalysts in the reduction of nitrate (NO3 −) [184]. Single-chamber electrochemical cells are simpler in design compared to dual-chamber cells. However, the potential oxidation of intermediate products formed during the electrocatalytic process within the single chamber may lead to a decrease in FE. In contrast, dual-chamber cells, separated by a proton exchange membrane, effectively prevent such oxidation, which is anticipated to result in higher ammonia production [185]. Nevertheless, the industrial scaling and commercialization of the electrochemical NRA synthesis process can be achieved through process optimization. Economically, single-chamber cells present certain advantages over dual-chamber cells, as they require fewer complex components and exhibit lower capital investment requirements. However, if adequate funding is available to support the design and development of dual-chamber cells, including the costs associated with Nafion membranes and the maintenance of active components, dual-chamber cells would emerge as the more advantageous option [186]. In recent years, there has been growing interest in optimizing flow cell reactors to further enhance the NH3 production rate and FE. These reactors can significantly improve reaction performance by refining electrode configurations and increasing electrolyte flow rates [187]. Particularly in large-scale industrial production, the design of electrocatalytic reactors must not only involve the selection and optimization of catalysts but also comprehensively address fluid dynamics, mass transfer efficiency, and the design of ion transport pathways. Regarding flow configurations, both single-channel and multi-channel reactors can be employed, with each configuration significantly influencing the efficiency of reactant-catalyst contact, reaction uniformity, and mass transfer. Single-channel reactors, while simple in design, are susceptible to concentration gradients that may result in non-uniform reactions. In contrast, multi-channel reactors increase the contact area between reactants and catalysts, thereby enhancing the uniform distribution of reactants and improving the reaction rate. Furthermore, the flow rate and residence time of the electrolyte are crucial factors that directly affect the conversion rate and the occurrence of side reactions. Lower flow rates and longer residence times facilitate improved reactant-catalyst contact, which can enhance NH3 yield. However, they may also promote side reactions, reducing selectivity for NH3 synthesis. On the other hand, higher flow rates can enhance mass transfer efficiency and mitigate side reactions, but may also shorten the contact time between reactants and catalysts, thereby affecting NO3 − conversion. As discussed above, it is clear that electrocatalytic NH3 synthesis technology remains at the laboratory scale. To transition this technology to industrial applications, several key challenges must be addressed. These include the rational selection of reactor types, a comprehensive evaluation of fluid dynamics, thermal management, electrode configuration, and the adaptation of mass transfer characteristics during scale-up. Furthermore, strategies such as modular design, parameter optimization, and real-time monitoring can accelerate the industrialization of electrocatalytic NRA systems. Therefore, optimizing the design of electrochemical cells will be crucial in overcoming current limitations and advancing the technology toward industrial application. 4 Research progress on electrocatalysts for NRA Based on the above discussion, it is clear that the complexity of nitrate reduction reaction and the diversity of its products present significant challenges and difficulties in improving the performance of electrocatalytic NRA. Electrocatalysts play a crucial role in the selective conversion of nitrate to ammonia, directly influencing the efficient production of ammonia. In recent decades, in the research on electrocatalytic NRA, researchers have extensively explored the feasibility of various metal and non-metal elements as electrocatalysts, providing valuable experience and theoretical foundations for finding effective ways to improve catalytic performance, as shown in Fig. 12 [59,188–190]. Notably, except for noble metals, transition metals (such as Fe, Cu, Ni, Co, and Ti) have exhibited great reactivity for the nitrate reduction reaction [191–193]. Additionally, some non-metals and p-block metals have also played important roles in the electrocatalytic NRA process [194,195]. Therefore, an in-depth study of the electrocatalytic performance of different types of catalysts, along with targeted designs based on their strengths and weaknesses, is an important crucial direction of research enhancing the performance of electrocatalytic NRA. 4.1 Pure metal catalysts Metal electrodes have long been a popular research material in the field of electrocatalysis due to their excellent conductivity and active polycrystalline surfaces. Different metal materials exhibit a range of physical and chemical properties and catalyze the electrochemical reduction of nitrate through various mechanisms and reaction pathways. There are significant differences between different metal catalysts in terms of reduction efficiency and ammonia selectivity. 4.1.1 Monometallic catalysts Earlier studies have shown that noble metals (such as Pt, Au, Ru and Pd) possess high corrosion resistance and exhibit outstanding activity in electrocatalytic NRA, effectively reducing nitrate in aqueous catholyte solutions [196–199]. Noble metals typically possess higher d-orbital energy levels and coordination numbers, which enable them to offer more reactive sites. This significantly enhances the adsorption of reactants and accelerates the reaction rate. Lim et al. investigated the effect of Pd surface structure on nitrate reduction by synthesizing nanocatalysts with different controllable crystal planes [200]. The study demonstrated that different Pd crystal facets exhibit significant differences in nitrate reduction activity in alkaline electrolytes, with the cubic octahedral structure exposing both Pd(111) and Pd(100) facets showing the highest ammonia yield (306.8 μg h−1 mgPd −1). Meanwhile, Liu et al. discovered ultra-high electrocatalytic NO3 − to NO2 − activity on oxide-derived silver (OD-Ag), achieving up to 98% selectivity and 95% FE [201]. Further reduction of accumulated NO2 − to NH4 + was well regulated by the cathodic potential and achieved an NH4 + FE of 89%. Li et al. reported a strained ruthenium nanocluster electrocatalyst for ammonia synthesis at room temperature [42]. Experimental results showed that the ammonia synthesis rate of this catalyst (5.56 mol h−1 gcat −1) exceeded that of the Haber-Bosch process, and the strained nanostructures maintained nearly 100% ammonia selectivity at the current density exceeding 120 mA cm−2 for 100 h. These research findings highlight the tremendous potential of noble metal catalysts in the NRA process. They not only provide a highly efficient and environmentally friendly pathway for low-temperature and low-pressure ammonia synthesis but also reveal that the precise design of catalyst surface structures can significantly improve the selectivity and yield of ammonia synthesis. However, the high cost and scarcity of noble metal catalysts remain challenges for widespread application, prompting researchers to seek more cost-effective alternative materials. Non-noble metal materials (such as Co, Fe, Cu and Ni) also exhibit excellent electrochemical properties, demonstrating significant potential for application [202–205]. Particularly, transition metals with unpaired d-electrons can effectively facilitate electron transfer and activate NO3 −, as the energy levels of these d-orbitals are close to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) energy level of NO3 − [206,207]. In addition, compared to noble metals, non-noble metals (such as Co, Fe, and Cu) typically have lower d-orbital energy levels and coordination numbers.
