This allows them to effectively balance the adsorption strength and desorption process of reactants, reduce the occurrence of side reactions, and improve the selectivity of the reaction. The metal Co has relatively low d-orbital energy levels, which favor electron transfer with the LUMO of intermediates such as NO3 −. This property, along with its high NH3 selectivity, has made Co a subject of extensive research. Singh et al. theoretically and experimentally investigated the catalytic activity of various transition metals (including Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn) for electrochemical NRA and determined that Co exhibited the highest NO3 − reduction activity [208]. Notably, oxide-derived Co (OD-Co) as an efficient NRA catalyst offers a maximum FE of 92.37% ± 6.7%. Using OD-Co as the cathode of a photovoltaic electrolyzer cell, a solar-driven electrochemical ammonia synthesis system using nitrates achieved an unprecedented solar-to-fuel efficiency of 11% for NH3 electrosynthesis (Fig. 13 a). Sun’s group reported Co-NCNT nanohybrids supported on carbon paper as a highly active electrocatalyst for the efficient reduction of NO3 − to NH3 [209]. In alkaline electrolytes, this catalyst exhibited a high NH3 yield of 5996 μg h−1 cm−2 and a high FE of 92%. Theoretical calculations on three different Co surface structures (Co (111), Co (200), and Co (220)) revealed that Co (111) is the most active surface for electrocatalytic NO3 − reduction (Fig. 13b). Furthermore, they also demonstrated a Co nanoparticle-decorated pomelo-peel-derived carbon (PP-Co) for electrocatalytic NO3 − reduction, achieving excellent NH3 synthesis performance (1.1 mmol h−1 mgcat −1, 90.1%) [210]. Wang et al. successfully constructed a high-dispersed Co nanoparticle decorated Juncus-derived carbon (Co@JDC) for electrocatalytic reduction of NO2 − to NH3 [211]. Notably, Co@JDC also exhibited excellent NH3 synthesis performance (NH3 yield: ∼2.1 mol h−1 gCo −1, FE: ∼93.2%) in electrocatalytic NO3 − reduction. Co@JDC supported on graphite felt was integrated into a photovoltaic‐electrolyzer cell as a bifunctional electrode, and the combined system achieved solar-driven NH3 electrosynthesis for 12 h. Fan et al. innovatively designed Co nanoparticles anchored on TiO2 nanobelt arrays on titanium plates (Co@TiO2/TP), enabling selective NH3 synthesis [212]. The Co@TiO2/TP electrocatalyst achieved a high NH3 yield of up to 800 μmol h−1 cm−2 and an FE of 96.7% in neutral solution, demonstrating remarkable stability during 50 h of electrolysis testing. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations indicated that Co@TiO2 promotes the adsorption of NO3 − in the solution and lowers the energy barrier of the rate-determining step. Fe is the active center of nitrogenase, and its use as an electrocatalytic material in NRA has made significant progress. Metallic iron sheets were originally used as cathode materials in electrochemical reactions, demonstrating excellent catalytic activity. Li et al. employed Ti/TiO2 as the anode and Fe, Al, Cu, and Ni as cathode materials in their study on the electrocatalytic reduction of NO3 − within a dual-chamber cell equipped with a cation exchange membrane [175]. Their findings revealed that the reduction efficiency of NO3 − by different cathodes follows the order: Fe > Al > Cu > Ni, which echoes the results presented in the research by Rao et al. (C > Ti ≈ Fe > Cu > Al) [203]. When Fe was used as the cathode, NO3 − was rapidly reduced to NH4 + without the accumulation of intermediate products (especially NO2 −) (Fig. 14 a). Whereas, despite the high catalytic performance of the iron cathode, the susceptibility of Fe to corrosion during use may lead to a decline in catalytic activity, limiting its potential as the optimal catalyst. To overcome this challenge, nanoscale iron, owing to its large specific surface area, has been widely studied, though its tendency to agglomerate increases the need for stability. In the study of electrocatalytic NRA, the use of non-metallic materials with high specific surface areas to form composites with nanoscale zero-valent iron can achieve a uniform distribution of iron-based catalysts. This approach not only protects iron particles from corrosion, but also effectively prevents their agglomeration [43]. Liu et al. exhibited FeOOH nanorod with Ovacanc supported on carbon paper (FeOOH/CP) as a high-performance catalyst for NH3 electrosynthesis at room temperature, achieving a high FE (92%) and NH3 yield (2419 μg h−1 cm−2) with excellent stability [213]. DFT calculations indicate that FeOOH (200) surfaces with oxygen vacancies facilitate more efficient adsorption of NO3 − compared to their counterparts without oxygen vacancies. Sun et al. inspired by nitrate reductase and artificial enzymes derived from inorganic nanomaterials, developed a novel nanozyme catalyst, FeNPs@MXene [214]. When applied to the electrocatalytic NRA, this catalyst demonstrated outstanding performance, achieving a nitrate conversion rate of up to 97.8% and an ammonium selectivity of up to 76.8%. Theoretical calculations revealed that the built-in electric field formed between FeOOH nanosheets and MXene promoted the adsorption of nitrate and lowered the reaction barriers of key intermediates. The FeNPs@MXene nanozyme accomplished three critical functions for the reduction of nitrate to ammonium: nitrate capture, nitrate dissociation, and ammonium release (Fig. 14b). This innovative iron-based electrocatalyst design offers new insightful perspectives for the NRA reaction. Recently, single-atom iron has emerged as a catalytic material, progressively garnering the interest of authors. Utilizing support materials to disperse single-atom iron maximizes the utilization of iron atoms as active sites, effectively suppressing competitive reactions (especially HER) and enhancing the efficiency of NO3 − reduction [215,216]. Wu et al. used SiO2 as a hard template to synthesize Fe single-atom catalyst (Fe SAC) via the carbonization method [217]. By dispersing metal atoms as isolated single atoms in the support, they achieved an optimized distribution of active sites, thereby avoiding N–N coupling and N2 formation during NO3 − reduction, significantly improving ammonia synthesis selectivity. Inspired by the unique and tunable local electronic structure, Li et al. designed an iron-based single-atom catalyst (Fe-PPy) derived from iron acetylacetonate/polypyrrole hydrogel precursor, which exhibited a high NH3 yield rate of 2.75 mg h−1 cm−2 and nearly 100% FE under alkaline conditions [218]. Due to the unique electronic structure and coordination state, the atomically dispersed Fe sites on the carbon matrix significantly enhanced the selectivity and activity of NO3 − electrocatalytic reduction to NH3 (Fig. 14c). The Fe sites in the isolated atomic state were more effective than Fe nanoparticles in adsorbing NO3 − and suppressing HER. Cu-based materials demonstrate robust electrocatalytic performance and enhanced ammonia selectivity for nitrate reduction across a spectrum of pH environments [219], including neutral [220–222], acidic [66,223], and alkaline conditions [224,225]. Despite the potential of bulk metallic copper in electrocatalytic NO3 − reduction, its application is limited by insufficient surface active sites and the inherently low reactivity of these sites [69]. To address these limitations, more efforts have been devoted to tuning the structure and morphology of monometallic Cu catalysts [226]. Recently, various nanostructured copper materials have exhibited admirable catalytic activity for selectively converting NO3 − into NH3. Fu et al. synthesized (111)-exposing Cu nanosheets via solution-phase synthesis for the electrocatalytic reduction of NO3 −, achieving an NH3 yield rate of 390.1 μg mgCu −1h−1 and a high FE of 99.7% [32]. Compared to Cu nanocubes and irregular Cu nanoparticles, competitive HER was more effectively suppressed on (111)-exposing Cu nanosheets, and the reaction rate of the rate-determining step was significantly enhanced (Fig. 15 a). Wu et al. synthesized uniform Cu nanodisks with exposed (111) facets for electrocatalytic NO3 − to NH3, and the catalyst achieved excellent NH3‐generation performance (NH3 yield rate: 2.16 mg mgcat −1h−1, FE: 81.1%) in alkaline conditions [227]. The catalytic ability of Cu nanodisks toward NRA can be ascribed to the surface-reconstructed triatomic Cu clusters, which are a result of the cathodic deoxygenation process. Beyond two-dimensional nanostructures, dendritic nanostructures emerge as another exemplary electrode material in electrocatalytic reactions. The edges and corners of these intricate structures are abounded with catalytically active atoms, effectively serving as prolific sites for catalysis and adsorption of reactant molecules. Li and colleagues developed a two-step conversion strategy using pre-synthesized Cu nanowire (Cu NW) as the starting material to construct hierarchical copper nanosheet-based Cu nanotubes (Cu NT) [191]. The Cu NT synthesized by this controllable reconstruction strategy achieved excellent NH3 generation performance with an ultrahigh FE of 85.7% and a high NH3 yield of 778.6 µg mg−1h−1. Noteworthily, during the electro-reduction process, copper-based nanomaterials tend to undergo surface reconstruction. Therefore, thoroughly investigating the active origin and structural evolution during electrochemical reactions is of great significance for the fundamental understanding and rational design of copper-based catalysts for the electrochemical synthesis of NH3 [228]. In this regard, surface defect engineering can effectively optimize the electrocatalytic performance of copper nanoparticles by precisely tuning their surface microstructure and electronic structure. Fang et al. demonstrated that oxide-derived Cu directly grown on Cu foam produced excellent ammonia selectivity (94%), NO3 − removal rate (93%), and FE (80%) [229]. During the electrocatalytic reduction of NO3 −, the original Cu oxide can be reduced to Cu (oxide-derived Cu) under negative potential, resulting in abundant stacking faults. The generated tensile strain effect facilitates the adsorption of NO3 − and makes the metallic Cu more active (Fig. 15b). Xu et al. demonstrated the conversion of CuO nanoplates into defect-rich Cu nanoplates (dr-Cu NPs) by in situ electroreduction, which exhibited significant NH3 yield rate (781.25 µg mg−1h−1) and FE (85.47%) [230]. Further experimental verification indicated that the enrichment of atomic defects in dr-Cu NPs contributes to the adsorption and accumulation of NO3 − and key reaction intermediates, while simultaneously suppressing side reactions, thereby selectively promoting NH3 synthesis (Fig. 15c). Monometallic catalysts have demonstrated unique advantages in the field of electrocatalytic NRA. Noble metal catalysts, with their excellent electronic conductivity and outstanding corrosion resistance, have shown remarkable performance in NRA studies. However, considering the cost and resource scarcity, research on noble metal catalysts is increasingly shifting towards more economical alloying and single-atom strategies. Meanwhile, non-noble metal catalysts, as a more cost-effective alternative, have proven their nitrogen reduction capabilities in both theoretical simulations and experimental studies. By finely tuning the crystal facets and microenvironment of the catalysts, the catalytic activity and ammonia selectivity of non-noble metal catalysts can be significantly enhanced. Therefore, whether noble or non-noble metals, well-designed monometallic catalysts exhibit significant potential for future applications in energy and environmental fields. 4.1.2 Bimetallic catalysts Combining different metal materials to exploit the synergistic effects between two or more metals has become a common and effective approach to optimizing the performance of metal catalysts. The electronic synergy between bimetallic components, along with changes in lattice parameters and valence electrons induced by alloying, results in properties of bimetallic catalysts that are significantly different from those of monometallic catalysts. These factors collectively enhance the stability and corrosion resistance of the catalysts, providing opportunities to develop novel catalysts with improved performance for specific reactions [231]. Introducing a second metal element through methods such as doping or alloying helps modify the distribution of the catalyst's electronic cloud density, resulting in a shift in the d-band center. This, in turn, allows the modulation of the adsorption strength of reaction intermediates. Therefore, considerable research is focused on using bimetallic catalysts to achieve nitrate reduction reactions. Bimetallic catalysts for NRA typically consist of a noble metal and a promoter metal [232], such as Pt/Rh alloys [233], Cu-Pt bimetallics [234], AuCu (111) single-atom alloys [235], and Rh@Cu catalysts [236]. Duca et al. employed pulsed laser deposition to synthesize preferentially oriented Ir, Rh, PtRh, and PtIr bimetallic alloy films on (100)-oriented MgO substrates [233]. After evaluating their electrochemical performance in a 0.5 M H2SO4 solution, they found that, compared to the single metals Ir and Rh, the bimetallic alloys exhibited lower reaction overpotentials and higher reduction current densities in the NO3 − reduction reaction, outperforming the pure metal catalysts. This enhancement can be attributed to the ligand and strain effects inherent in the bimetallic catalysts. Furthermore, the study suggests that by tuning the Pt content in the alloy, both the catalyst's activity and selectivity can be further optimized, providing a promising strategy for efficient NH3 synthesis. Intermetallic single-atom alloys (ISAA), which combine the advantages of nanocrystals and single-atom catalysts while maintaining a high density of single-atom sites, can effectively promote the NRA reaction. Xie et al. reported an ISAA In-Pd bimetallic catalyst with a few atomic layers and an intermetallic body-centered cubic structure for selective electrocatalytic NRA [237]. In the ISAA In-Pd system, Pd single atoms are effectively isolated by surrounding In atoms, which significantly reduce the overlap of Pd d-orbitals and weaken the p-d hybridization between In-p and Pd-d states near the Fermi level. This enhancement of NO3 − adsorption and the reduction in the energy barrier of the rate-determining step of the NRA reaction lead to improved catalytic performance. When applied in a tri-functional Zn-NO3 − flow battery, the catalyst achieves a power density of 12.64 mW cm−2 and an FE of 93.4% for NH3 production. This study offers new insights for the design of efficient NRA electrocatalysts. With advancements in computational modeling techniques and research methodologies, non-PGM (platinum group metal) alloys have also demonstrated high performance in the field of electrocatalytic NRA [238]. Among various metallic materials, Fe stands out for its superior catalytic reduction capabilities, whereas Cu is particularly selective in converting NO3 − into NO2 − [239]. Consequently, the Fe/Cu alloy electrode emerges as a highly promising candidate for an efficient cathode material in NO3 − reduction applications. Zhao et al. conducted a comprehensive comparative study on the NRA performance of three bimetallic catalysts, CuNi, CuCo, and CuFe, using ordered mesoporous carbon (OMC) as the catalyst support [240]. The results revealed that at a reduction potential of − 0.8 V (versus RHE), the optimal NH3 yield followed the order: Cu5Fe5/OMC > Cu5Co5/OMC > Cu7Ni3/OMC. Additionally, compared to monometallic catalysts, the bimetallic catalysts exhibited higher performance due to the strong synergistic effects between the metals. Utilizing a cathodic electrochemical deposition strategy, Zhang and colleagues designed and fabricated Fe/Cu foam electrodes as cathode materials for nitrate reduction reactions [241]. The Fe/Cu electrode achieved an impressive 98.6% efficiency in reducing NO3 − within 90 min, significantly surpassing the respective efficiencies of copper foam (24.3%) and iron (76.0%) when used as cathode materials. In a study by Tang et al., Cu-Fe bimetallic nanoalloys with adjustable ratios were successfully synthesized using CuCl2 and FeCl3 as raw materials through a reaction mechanical ball milling method [242]. In a neutral electrolyte, the optimized Cu3Fe exhibited an excellent NO3 − reduction efficiency of 81.1% and an NH3 selectivity of 70.3%. This performance improvement was attributed to the introduction of Fe, which caused an upward shift in the d-band center of Cu, thereby enhancing the adsorption of NO3 − on the Cu3Fe surface (Fig. 16 a). Additionally, the activity of Fe in catalyzing hydrogen evolution effectively accelerated the stepwise hydrogenation process, significantly increasing the selectivity towards NH4 +. This finding aligns with the results obtained by Wang et al., who synthesized a metasequoia-like nanocrystal of CuFe [243]. To mitigate the competition from the HER for catalytic active sites, Zhou et al. proposed an innovative strategy of anchoring Cu single atoms onto the amorphous iron oxide shell of nanoscale zero-valent iron (nZVI), resulting in the formation of a Cu1-Fe dual-site catalyst [244]. The enhanced adsorption of NO3 − at the Fe site and the activation of H2O at the Cu site work synergistically, effectively lowering the energy barrier for the conversion of NO to NOH, thereby improving reaction efficiency. The catalyst exhibited remarkable stability over more than 20 cycles, achieving a 94.8% NO3 − conversion rate and 99.2% ammonia selectivity. Additionally, by combining electrochemical nitrate reduction with in situ ammonia recovery, the study introduced a hybrid system with a nitrogen recovery rate exceeding 92%, providing a novel strategy for the treatment of neutral nitrate wastewater and the efficient utilization of nitrogen resources. Besides Fe-Cu bimetallic catalysts, other bimetallic catalysts composed of non-precious metal combinations have also been widely applied in NRA. Bai et al. demonstrated that Cu-Ni alloy displays both stability and remarkable efficiency during the NRA process. Under optimal conditions, the reduction efficiency of NO3 − within 4 h reached an impressive 83.87%, with a strong ammonia selectivity as high as 93.6% [245]. The study of electronic structure revealed that the incorporation of Ni facilitates the elevation of the d-band center energy level of the catalyst, thereby enhancing the adsorption of NO3 − and possible reaction intermediates (Fig. 16b). Liu group successfully synthesized highly dispersed face-centered cubic CuCo alloy using an ultrafast carbothermal shock method [221]. The as-designed catalyst exhibited a remarkable ammonia yield of 164.23 mmol h−1 cm−2 and an outstanding FE of 96.29% in neutral electrolyte. Gao et al. prepared a series of RuCu alloy catalysts supported on reduced graphene oxide (rGO) (Ru x Cu x /rGO) for electrocatalytic NRA [246]. The catalyst exhibited a high ammonia FE of 98% at an ultra-low potential of − 0.05 V vs. RHE. In situ Raman spectroscopy and DFT calculations showed that during the electrocatalytic NRA process, NO2* was generated, desorbed and converted into NH3 on the surface of the CuRu alloy through relay catalysis (Fig. 16c). The NRA performance of bimetallic catalysts is largely influenced by the metal doping ratio [234,247]. Yang et al. prepared Ce-doped Cu electrodes by electrochemical deposition method and investigated the effect of Ce doping content on electrode performance [248]. The experimental results revealed that Cu10Ce10 demonstrated the best performance, achieving an impressive ammonia yield rate of 0.99 mmol h−1 cm−2 and an FE of 98.43%. Theoretical studies indicated that the ammonia selectivity of up to 79.33% benefited from the Cu/Cu2O interfacial structure formed on the CuCe electrode, which acts as an active phase, modulating the electronic structure of copper and thereby reducing the overpotential for NO3 − reduction. In another example, Jeon and co-workers verified the excellent NH3 ‐production performance of Co–Cu (Co1− x Cu x ) nanoparticles supported on a three-dimensional substrate during the electrocatalytic NRA process [249]. Typically, the optimized Co0.5Cu0.5 catalyst performed over 95% FE, which is 7.3- and 1.7-fold higher than that of pure Co and Cu counterparts. The NRA performance was significantly enhanced by adjusting the onset potential of catalysis through substituting Co with Cu, which is of significance for the selective reduction of nitrate to ammonia. These findings provide valuable insights into the development of bimetallic catalysts in the field of electrocatalytic NRA, potentially inspiring further research and exploration in this area. 4.1.3 High-entropy alloy catalysts In recent years, high-entropy alloys (HEAs), composed of five or more elements, have emerged as highly promising materials in catalysis, owing to their exceptional mechanical strength, superior thermal stability, and remarkable corrosion resistance [250]. HEAs, with their distinctive surface adsorption sites and atomic arrangements optimized via phase engineering, are considered highly efficient catalysts for multi-step electrocatalytic reactions, significantly enhancing electrochemical performance [251]. Zhang et al. were the first to apply high-entropy alloys (HEA, FeCoNiAlTi) to the electrocatalytic NRA reaction [252]. Through an effective phase engineering strategy, uniformly dispersed intermetallic nanoparticles were introduced into the bulk FeCoNiAlTi catalyst. Benefiting from its increased active surface area and accelerated charge transfer processes, the catalyst achieved a high NH3 production rate of 0.52 mg h−1 cm−2 and an FE of 95.23% at −0.5 V. This study expands the application of high-entropy alloys and phase engineering in electrocatalytic NRA, demonstrating their potential in efficient ammonia synthesis. Subsequently, the application of high-entropy alloys (HEAs) in electrocatalytic NRA has garnered significant attention. Hao et al. introduced a “surface entropy reduction” strategy by depositing a few atomic layers of silver (FL-Ag) onto the surface of HEA, thereby synthesizing the FL-Ag/HEA catalyst [253]. This catalyst exhibited outstanding NH3 synthesis performance (NH3 yield rate: 2.45 mmol h−1 mgcat −1, FE: 92.7%) and excellent long-term stability (200 h) in neutral media, significantly surpassing most advanced electrocatalysts and traditional H-B processes. Mechanistic studies revealed that FL-Ag promoted efficient NO3 − to NO conversion by creating distinct active sites on the HEA substrate, followed by hydrogenation of NO to NH3 on Pd sites at the HEA-FL-Ag interface. This multi-site relay catalysis mechanism not only enhanced reaction selectivity and activity but also effectively lowered the reaction energy barrier, improving overall catalytic efficiency. Additionally, FL-Ag optimized the electronic structure of the HEA surface, further boosting the electrochemical performance of the nitrogen reduction reaction. To optimize electrocatalytic NRA performance, Tang et al. reported a scalable high-entropy single-atom nanocage (HESA NC) catalyst based on cyanogel [254]. By introducing element heterogeneity into the lattice of cyanogel nanocubes, a unique structure was constructed with Fe as the main component and five metals—Co, Cu, Zn, Cd, and In—isolated by cyanide bridges and covalently coordinated with C and N. The study systematically investigated the formation mechanism of HESA NCs and the impact of high-entropy effects on electrocatalytic NRA performance. The entropy-induced reduction in single-atom lattice symmetry, coupled with enhanced hydrolysis and hydrogenation processes, enabled the catalyst to exhibit excellent activity, selectivity, and durability. An FE of 93.4% and an NH3 production rate of 81.4 mg h−1 mg−1 were achieved over 20 consecutive electrolysis cycles. This study provides valuable insights for designing scalable catalysts with high-entropy single-atom hollow nanostructures. Zhu et al. embedded Pt-based high-entropy intermetallic (HEI) nanoparticles (NPs) into a two-dimensional nitrogen-doped mesoporous carbon framework to optimize electrocatalytic NRA performance [255]. By finely tuning the composition (up to eight elements) and atomic order (>90%) of HEI NPs, they provided a rich material selection for NH3 synthesis. Among the three designed five-component HEI catalysts, Pt0.8Fe0.2Co0.2Ni0.2Cu0.2 exhibited high NH3 FE (>97%) and excellent cycling stability (>20 cycles) under both acidic and alkaline conditions. In situ experiments and DFT calculations revealed that the catalyst's multi-site synergistic effect optimized the adsorption of NO x and the generation of H species, enhancing NH3 synthesis efficiency. This study offers new perspectives for the design of high-entropy catalysts. The unique surface electronic structure of metals enables effective adsorption and activation of NO3 −. Additionally, differences in surface energy and work potential among metals allow pure metal catalysts to offer specific active sites, facilitating the reduction of NO3 −. High-entropy catalysts, as a new class of materials, demonstrate superior catalytic performance over conventional single-metal or bimetallic catalysts by incorporating multiple metal elements to form solid solutions. The synergistic interaction among multiple metal elements induces unique modulation of the electronic structure, which promotes the adsorption and activation of NO3 −. By precisely controlling the crystal structure and particle size of the metals, the catalytic performance can be further optimized, enhancing selectivity toward the target reaction. Table 1 summarizes the performance of various pure metal catalysts. 4.2 Metal oxide catalysts 4.2.1 Monometallic oxide catalysts Metal oxide electrodes play a crucial role in electrocatalytic NRA [256,257]. For example, single metal oxide TiO2, known for its eco-friendly and corrosion-resistant properties, has been the focus of extensive efforts to design and develop high-performance TiO2-based NRA electrocatalysts [258–260]. Jia et al. were the first to synthesize TiO2 nanotubes with abundant Ovacancy (TiO2− x ), which exhibited excellent NH3 yield (0.045 mmol h−1 mg−1) and NH3 selectivity (87.1%), with an FE as high as 85.0% [261]. Online differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS) and DFT calculations revealed that the oxygen atoms in NO3 − could fill the oxygen vacancies in TiO2− x , thereby weakening the N–O bond strength and effectively suppressing the formation of by-products (Fig. 17 a) [262]. Zhao et al. conducted an in-depth study on the NRA activity of Co-doped TiO2 nanoribbon arrays supported on a Ti plate (Co-TiO2/TP), and the catalyst achieved a high NH3 yield of 1127 µmol h−1 cm−2 and an FE of 98.2% in alkaline solution, which is superior to the pristine TiO2/TP (88.5 µmol h−1 cm−2, 35.1%) [263]. In another experiment, Chen et al. proposed using iron as a doping atom to enhance the electrocatalytic NO3 −-to-NH3 conversion over TiO2 [264]. As expected, the Fe-TiO2/TP catalyst showed excellent performance in alkaline media (940.17 µmol h−1 cm−2, 95.93%). Theoretical calculations further unveiled that Fe doping significantly improved the electronic conductivity of TiO2 and optimized the adsorption of active species on the catalyst surface (Fig. 17b). In addition, monometallic Co oxide was also found to be active [265,266]. Su et al. first prepared Co3O4 films supported on a Ti substrate as cathode material for nitrate reduction reaction, achieving good NO3 − reduction efficiency and NH3 yield [123]. However, the electrocatalytic performance of Co3O4 is greatly limited by its low electrical conductivity. In order to improve the electrocatalytic activity of Co3O4, a series of catalyst synthesis strategies have been proposed, such as doping, defect engineering [267,268], valence state engineering [269], and heterojunction construction [270]. Lu et al. synthesized a Ru-Co3O4 catalyst by incorporating Ru atoms into the octahedral sites of Co3O4, achieving an NH3 production rate of 24.6 mg h−1 cm−2 in the electrocatalytic NRA [271]. Electrochemical in situ spectroscopy and theoretical calculations revealed that the Ru sites efficiently and stably promoted NH3 synthesis by optimizing the adsorption of H2O and facilitating the generation of active hydrogen species (H*). Furthermore, in the Ru-Co3O4-based Zn-NO3 − battery system, the catalyst achieved a peak power density of 32.28 mW cm−2 and an FE of 98.2% for NH3, demonstrating its practical application potential. This study presents a novel approach to enhance nitrate (NO3 −) reduction efficiency and catalyze other hydrogenation reactions more effectively through the synergistic modulation of active sites. Xu et al. constructed oxygen vacancy-rich Co3O4 nanorarrays grown on carbon cloth (vO-Co3O4/CC) as an efficient NRA electrocatalyst [267]. The experimental results indicated that this catalyst exhibited a superior NH3 yield (12157 µg h−1 cm−2) and FE (96.9%) in electrocatalytic NO3 − reduction compared to the Co3O4/CC catalyst. In contrast, Deng et al. designed Co vacancy-rich Co3O4 nanorarrays on carbon cloth (vCo-Co0O4/CC) as a self-supported electrode, which also demonstrated excellent electrocatalytic performance [268]. DFT calculations revealed that the introduction of Co vacancies modulated the electronic structure of Co3O4, leading to an increase in charge at the active sites, which facilitated the adsorption of NO3 − on Co sites and reduced the energy barrier of the *NHO to *NHOH reaction process, resulting in high catalytic performance. Fu et al. verified that the synergy between Co (III) and Co (II) in the Co3O4/carbon felt electrode can significantly enhance the catalytic performance of the catalyst with 3D structure [269]. The study found that the key mechanism for the excellent catalytic performance of Co3O4 lies in the different roles played by Co (III) and Co (II) in the NO3 − reduction reaction. With Co (III) exhibiting a preference for NO3 − adsorption, while Co (II) was more inclined to adsorb H (Fig. 17c). By finely regulating the ratio of Co (III) to Co (II) on the Co3O4/carbon felt electrode, researchers can effectively modulate the overall performance of the catalyst. Besides TiO2 and Co monometallic oxides, Fe and Cu monometallic oxides also exhibit excellent NRA activity [272–275]. These findings provide key theoretical insights for designing efficient metal oxide NRA electrocatalysts. 4.2.2 Bimetallic oxide catalysts Nevertheless, single metal oxides still face certain limitations and challenges in terms of conductivity, NO3 − adsorption, and HER suppression. To address these difficulties, bimetallic oxides, such as FeCO2O4 [276] ZnCO2O4 [277], and NiCO2O4 [278], have been widely applied in electrocatalytic NRA in recent years. Relevant studies have shown that bimetallic oxides tend to exhibit more flexible ion arrangements and higher conductivity. Moreover, the superior catalytic activity of bimetallic oxides can be attributed to the effective optimization of intermediate adsorption energy and the microenvironment regulation resulting from the interaction between the two metal elements. This not only enhances NO3 − adsorption but also effectively suppresses HER. Compared to Co3O4, ZnCO2O4 nanosheet arrays could achieve an FE of 98.33% and provide nearly twice the NH3 yield in alkaline solution [277]. Li et al. investigated the performance of the electrocatalytic NRA on an MnCO2O4 nanowire array [279]. In alkaline medium, the self-supported MnCO2O4 electrode grown on carbon cloth (MnCO2O4/CC) exhibited an outstanding FE of 97.1% and an NH3 yield of 0.67 mmol h−1 cm−2. DFT analysis indicated that the incorporation of Mn enhanced the adsorption of NO3 − on the electrocatalyst, while the spinel structure improved the conductivity of the catalyst (Fig. 18 a). These improvements significantly increased the activity of MnCO2O4/CC in NRA. Similarly, the performance of the electrocatalytic NRA was studied on NiCO2O4/CC nanowire array [278]. As expected, NiCO2O4/CC achieved a high FE of 99.0% and an NH3 yield of up to 973.2 µmol h−1 cm−2. The substitution of Co3+ by Ni2+ at octahedral sites facilitated electron transfer during the electrocatalytic NRA process, resulting in superior catalytic activity for NiCO2O4 (Fig. 18b). Additionally, the introduction of Ni optimized the adsorption capacity for NO3 − [280]. Therefore, compared to Co3O4, NiCO2O4 demonstrated significant superiority in both enhanced conductivity and HER suppression, which are key factors contributing to the improved NRA performance. Yang et al. prepared CuO-Co3O4/Ti bimetallic oxide composite catalytic electrode by modifying Ti electrodes with Cu and Co, thereby increasing the NO3 − reduction efficiency of Ti electrode from 55.9% to nearly 100% [281]. Furthermore, compared with the Co3O4/Ti electrode, the CuO-Co3O4/Ti electrode exhibited superior hydrogen evolution performance, ensuring high selectivity towards NH3. This may be attributed to the unclosed d-orbital shells and unoccupied π* orbitals in CuO, which increased the adsorption of NO3 − on CuO and thereby accelerated the NO3 − reduction process. The formation of heterojunctions can optimize carrier distribution and electronic structure by modulating the interface effects between different materials, facilitating efficient interactions between reactants and active sites, thereby significantly enhancing the overall catalytic performance. Sun’s group constructed a TiO2 nanoarray heterojunction catalyst decorated with Co3O4 nanosheets (Co3O4@TiO2) [270]. In the heterostructure formed between Co3O4 and TiO2, the interfacial built-in electric field between the two materials optimized electron migration kinetics, which enhanced the catalyst surface's ability to capture NO3 −, thereby improving catalytic efficiency. Consequently, the as-prepared catalyst delivered excellent NRA performance (NH3 yeild rate: 875 μmol h−1 cm−2, FE: 93.1%) in an alkaline environment, superior to the pristine Co3O4 and TiO2. Theoretical calculations revealed that the combination of Co3O4 with TiO2 effectively modulated the electronic structure and significantly enhanced the conductivity of Co3O4@TiO2, thereby improving its catalytic activity. Additionally, the rate-determining step in the catalytic process (conversion of NO to *N) was effectively promoted on this catalyst, and HER was effectively suppressed, ensuring high selectivity towards NH3. In summary, research on metal oxide catalysts has revealed a low-cost electrocatalytic method for nitrogen reduction. Several metal oxide catalysts and their performance are listed in Table 2 . Polymetallic oxide electrodes exhibit superior reduction performance in NRA compared to single metal oxide electrodes, due to their more diverse physicochemical properties, higher specific surface area, and enhanced catalytic activity. The development of high-performance catalysts can be achieved through effective design and precise regulation of bimetallic catalysts. 4.3 Other metal compound catalysts In addition to metal oxides, various other metal compounds, including metal sulfides, metal phosphides, and metal nitrides, have gained significant attention and have been extensively utilized in electrocatalytic NRA in recent years. Metal phosphides have been proven the high catalytic activity for facilitating NO x −‐to‐NH3 conversion [282,283]. Ye et al. reported CoP nanosheet arrays on carbon fiber cloth (CoP NAs/CFC) for electrocatalytic nitrate reduction reaction [284]. Under alkaline conditions, CoP NAs/CFC demonstrated nearly 100% FE and a considerable NH3 yield, far surpassing the Haber-Bosch process. Operando XANES characterization indicated that the prerequisite for NO3 − reduction on CoP is the excitation of electrons from the Co 3d orbitals to the 4p orbitals, so that the excited electrons can be further injected into the π* orbitals of NO3 − through the Co–O–N bond, rendering the adsorbed NO3 − unstable and thus reduced. Additionally, DFT calculations indicate that the introduction of P reduces the energy barrier of the rate-determining step, thereby facilitating the conversion of NO3 − to NH3. PdP2 is explored as an efficient catalyst for the electrocatalytic NRA. Wang’s group conducted an in-depth study of the electrocatalytic NRA mechanism of PdP2 nanoparticles on reduced graphene oxide (PdP2/rGO) [285]. They examined the adsorption characteristics of NO3 − on the PdP2 surface in three different geometric configurations: top Pd site 1, top Pd site 2, and bridge Pd site. By comparing the adsorption-free energies of NO3 − at different sites, the study found that the bridge Pd site is more favorable for NO3 − adsorption. Furthermore, electronic state analysis revealed significant hybridization between the p-orbital of NO3 − and the d-orbital of Pd, indicating a strong interaction between Pd and NO3 −. Theoretical calculations presented that the PdP2 surface can not only effectively activate and hydrogenate NO3 −, but also partially inhibit HER. Ni-based electrocatalysts have garnered considerable interest for their role in ambient NH3 production, particularly through the electrochemical NRA process. Yao et al. successfully synthesized Ni2P with a (111) crystal facet in situ on nickel foam through a one-step phosphidation method, which served as a self-supported cathode for NRA [205]. Ni2P exhibited outstanding NO3 − removal efficiency (86.6%), high NH3 selectivity (89.1%), and impressive FE (99.23%). DFT calculations revealed that during the deoxygenation of NO3 −, NO2 and NO are formed, NO then undergoes further hydrogenation to produce NH3, and this process is exothermic. Ni2P demonstrated a unique super-hydrophilic surface, metallic characteristics, low resistance, and abundant surface-active sites, which are conducive to NO3 − adsorption and hydrogen atom generation, thereby effectively promoting the hydrogenation of NO3 −. By introducing electronegative p-block non-metal elements like S in combination with transition metals, the electronic structure of the metal can be effectively modulated, optimizing its catalytic performance. Zhang et al. synthesized Cu-Co binary sulfide nanosheets with Cu7.2S4/CoS2 interfaces, and by adjusting the Cu/Co ratio, they achieved optimization of the catalytic performance in NRA [286]. The experimental results demonstrate that the optimal catalyst Cu x S-Co0.5 achieved an NH3 production rate of 5.36 mg h−1 cm−2 and an NH3 FE of 77.6%, which are 6.5 and 3.8 times higher than those of pure Cu x S and CoS2, respectively. This suggests that adjusting the ratio of Cu x S and Co can significantly enhance the catalyst's activity and selectivity in the NO3 − reduction reaction. Spectral analysis and DFT calculations reveal the presence of a nanoscale built-in electric field at the Cu7.2S4/CoS2 interface, which enhances the local electronic density, thereby creating more active sites for the reaction. At the same time, the introduction of CoS2 improved the conductivity of Cu x -Co0.5, reduced electron transfer resistance, and provided an adequate supply of *H for the subsequent hydrogenation process. The synergistic effect between the two components significantly enhanced the electrocatalytic NRA activity. This study offers a novel approach for designing bimetallic sulfide catalysts with rich built-in electric fields. Wang et al. suggest that Mo-based catalysts with sulfur vacancies can effectively capture NO3 − and enhance its electrocatalytic reduction [287]. To this end, they synthesized a MoS2 electrocatalyst with sulfur vacancies (SV-MoS2) through a one-step hydrothermal method. DFT calculations show that the presence of sulfur vacancies effectively lowers the energy barrier of the potential-determining step in the NO3 − reduction reaction, suppresses the formation of NO2 and N2 by-products and enhances the selectivity for NH3 synthesis. In addition, when both *N and *H coexist at the sulfur vacancies, the formation of *NH is thermodynamically more favorable, while the formation of H2 does not exhibit a thermodynamic advantage. Finally, the SV-MoS2 catalyst exhibited an excellent NH3 yield of up to 76.67 μg h−1 mgcat −1. SnS2, a two-dimensional sulfide material with a high specific surface area and excellent electrochemical properties, has also been extensively studied in various fields [288]. For the electrocatalytic NRA, the metallic sites of SnS2 are typically covered by sulfur atoms, which limits its surface activity. Therefore, modification treatments are necessary to enhance its catalytic performance. Li et al. employed a combination of vacancy engineering and heteroatom doping strategies to develop Cu-doped SnS2 nanoflowers (Cu-SnS2− x ) with abundant sulfur vacancies as electrocatalysts [289]. Due to the synergistic effect between Cu and S, the Cu-SnS2− x nanocatalyst achieved an excellent NH3 production rate of 0.63 mmol h−1 mgcat −1 and an FE of 93.8% in an alkaline medium at − 0.7 V vs. RHE, nearly doubling the performance of the original SnS2. DFT calculations confirmed that the presence of sulfur vacancies facilitated the transfer of free electrons to the Sn center, enhancing the catalytic activity for the nitrate reduction reaction. The introduction of Cu further modulated the electron distribution and stabilized the reaction intermediates, thereby significantly enhancing the efficiency of NH3 synthesis. Transition metal nitrides, with their distinct d-orbital electronic structure and optimized lattice configuration, have emerged as promising materials in the field of electrocatalysis. Jiang et al. synthesized a low-cost nitrogen-doped biochar supported with Fe nanoparticles (Fe-NBC) from nitrogen-rich wetland plants for the electrocatalytic reduction of NO3 − [290]. The study shows that the Fe-NBC treated at 600 °C exhibits excellent NO3 − reduction performance and NH3 yield, reaching 78.6 μmol h−1 mgcat −1. Kinetic analysis shows that the reaction rate of Fe-NBC is 1.5 times faster than that of Fe-embedded biochar and 3.5 times faster than that of bare N-doped biochar. Characterization and experimental results indicate that the pyridinic nitrogen in the FeN x sites of Fe-NBC accelerates electron transfer, significantly enhancing the electrocatalytic activity for NO3 − reduction. In addition, the biochar structure prevents the aggregation and dissolution of Fe nanoparticles, ensuring the excellent stability of Fe-NBC during the reaction. The complex of metal centers and nitrogen ligands serves as a typical representative system for catalytic hydrogenation reactions in small molecule conversion. Gong et al. synthesized Co4N and Co3CuN with an anti-perovskite structure as model catalysts and investigated the effect of the coupling between the metal centers and nitrogen ligands on the hydrogenation process in electrocatalytic NRA [291]. Combining DFT calculations and spectroscopic analysis, the study found that the introduction of Cu enhanced the coupling of the Co–N bond, altered the charge distribution of the Co sites, and shifted the Co 3d band toward the Fermi level. This effectively promoted the adsorption of NO3 − and *H, thereby improving the electrocatalytic nitrate reduction performance. Electrochemical experiments show that Co3CuN exhibits significantly better electrocatalytic activity than the original Co4N, achieving an optimal Faradaic efficiency of 97% and an NH3 production rate of 455.3 mmol h−1 cm−2 at −0.3 V vs. RHE. This study demonstrates that adjusting the coupling between metal centers and nitrogen ligands in heterogeneous catalysts is an effective strategy for developing high-performance catalysts, offering promising applications in energy conversion and environmental remediation. In addition to metal phosphides, sulfides, and nitrides, other types of metal compounds, such as metal carbides and metal compound complexes [292,293], have also garnered significant attention in recent years due to their promising catalytic properties in various electrocatalytic reactions [294,295]. It also demonstrates significant potential for application in the field of electrocatalytic NRA. In recent years, with the continuous advancement of research, these materials have garnered increasing attention and are considered promising candidates for enhancing electrocatalytic performance (Table 3 ). 4.4 Carbon-based non-metal catalysts Carbon-based non-metallic catalysts, noted for their environmental friendliness, low toxicity, low cost, and exceptional corrosion resistance, have attracted considerable attention in the field of electrocatalysis. Carbon-based catalysts, such as boron-doped diamond (BDD) [296], graphite [297,298], and charcoal [299], have exhibited high performance in the NRA field, thereby further reinforcing their significance as a focal point of research [300]. Ding et al. compared the electrocatalytic performance of different cathode materials, including graphite felt, Cu-Ni alloy, and titanium, for NRA [169]. Under identical experimental conditions, NO3 − exhibited the highest reduction efficiency on the graphite felt electrode, compared to the Cu90Ni10 and titanium metal electrodes. Lacasa and colleagues investigated the impact of various metal and carbon-based non-metal materials (including conductive diamond, stainless steel, silicon carbide, graphite, and lead) as cathode materials on the removal efficiency of NO3 − [301]. The study results indicated that stainless steel and graphite cathodes exhibited higher selectivity for the generation of NH4 + in the solution. Charcoal demonstrated higher efficiency in the NO3 − reduction reaction, which may be attributed to its higher sp3/sp2 carbon atom ratio significantly enhancing the electron transfer kinetics during the NO3 − reduction process [299]. Additionally, as an electrocatalytic energy storage material, charcoal can offer more active sites through the interaction of C–O bonds and other oxygen-containing functional groups during charge–discharge cycles, thereby further enhancing the activity for electrocatalytic reduction of NO3 −. By transforming household waste into carbon-based catalysts with practical application value, this approach not only helps reduce environmental pollution and lower the production costs of catalysts but also promotes the recycling of resources and technological innovation. This strategy provides an effective pathway for achieving sustainable development and establishing an environmentally friendly economic model. Li et al. investigated the NRA performance of fluorine-doped carbon (CF) used as a catalyst, which was derived from pyrolyzed cigarette butt recyclables treated with a polytetrafluoroethylene solution [302]. The as-prepared catalyst demonstrated excellent catalytic performance, with an ammonia production rate of 23.8 mmol h−1 gcat −1, which is 2 to 4 times higher than that of single carbon used as an electrocatalyst. Analysis based on DFT revealed that doping with fluorine effectively lowered the energy barrier for the hydrogenation reaction of NO3 − and inhibited the competition from the HER. The development and exploration of Carbon-based non-metallic catalysts are of scientific significance and economic value for electrocatalytic NRA. These catalysts, by introducing heteroatoms with varying electronegativities and atomic radii, promote an increase in the free electrons within the π orbitals of the carbon framework, effectively enhancing the catalytic activity [112,303,304]. Research on Carbon-based non-metallic catalysts not only reduces the reliance on rare and expensive metals but also holds indispensable significance in advancing sustainable chemical production and green chemical processes. 4.5 Composite catalysts Composite electrocatalysts, constituted of metal and non-metal materials, demonstrate pronounced advantages for electrocatalysis. This is predominantly attributed to their synergistic structural and compositional attributes, which amalgamate to form an exceptional union of properties (Table 4 ). Metal and non-metal materials always play critical and complementary roles in composite electrocatalysts. Metals primarily serve as the active centers for catalysis, providing the necessary electronic states and surface sites. On the other hand, non-metal materials act as the supporting structure, where their larger specific surface area not only enhances the dispersion of metal particles but also effectively improves the overall conductivity and electron transport efficiency of the catalyst. The synergy between these two components enhances the activity, stability, and selectivity of composite electrocatalysts in NRA, facilitating an efficient electrocatalytic NRA process. For example, Zhong et al. proposed Co3O4 nanoparticles embedded in porous carbon nanofibers (Co3O4@CNF) as an efficient catalyst for NRA [305]. Due to the relatively low NO3 − adsorption energy of Co3O4 clusters, Co3O4@CNF demonstrates a high Faradaic efficiency of up to 92.7% and an ammonia production rate of 23.4 mg h−1 mgcat −1, while also exhibiting excellent electrochemical stability. Çirmi et al. developed a polypyrrole-coated copper electrode (PPy-Cu) for efficient NRA, where the copper electrode surface is coated with a polypyrrole layer [101]. Compared to the bare copper electrode, PPy-Cu did not produce significant changes in the types of catalytic products, but it notably altered the yield and ratio of these products. Within the low potential range of −0.4 to −0.8 V, PPy effectively facilitated the conversion of NO3 − to NH3 by adsorbing protons from the solution and promoting electron transfer to PPy, thereby generating atomic hydrogen. The disappearance of NO2 − in the PPy-Cu catalytic system further supports this view, which improves the selectivity of ammonia in this system. For other composite electrocatalysts, Li et al. designed a copper foam electrode-derived beaded nanowire heterostructure catalyst (o-CoP/C@Cu3P/CF) [306]. The synergistic catalytic effect was achieved through the bifunctional active sites in the heterostructure, including a moderate *NO x anchoring effect, sufficient *H supply, and fast *H transfer, which were fully verified in in situ ATR-SEIRAS and SHINERS characterizations (Fig. 19 a, b). In a solution containing 100 mM NO3 −, the self-supporting electrode exhibited an excellent NH3 yield of 1.571 ± 0.046 mmol h−1 cm−2. Furthermore, Guan et al. prepared n%-Co3O4/SiC (n = 5, 8, 12, 20) catalysts with precise Co2+ and Co3+ ratios for NRA [307]. The study revealed that Co3+ primarily catalyzes the reduction of NO3 − to NO2 −, while Co2+ is responsible for converting NO2 − to NH3. In situ ATR-SEIRAS characterization was used to further quantitatively analyze nitrogen-containing intermediates and validate the reaction mechanism (Fig. 19c). Ultimately, 8%-Co3O4/SiC exhibited an NH3 yield of 1.08 mmol h−1 cm−2 at −0.89 V vs. RHE, with an FE of 96.4%, outperforming most reported non-precious metal catalysts. Metal-Organic Framework (MOF) materials are porous structures composed of metal nodes and organic linkers. These materials have attracted widespread attention in the field of electrocatalysis due to their high specific surface area, excellent thermal and chemical stability, and remarkable design flexibility [308,309]. It has been demonstrated that the unsaturated coordination environment of single metal sites within MOF materials can significantly enhance the catalytic efficiency of various reactions [310–312]. Therefore, as supports for the preparation of single-site catalysts, MOF materials show great potential and prospects. Feng’s group developed a Cu-MOF-derived compound anchored on carbon nitride nanosheets with isolated copper single atoms [313]. By thermally treating Cu-MOFs at 800 °C, they successfully synthesized unique carbon nanosheets embedded with isolated copper atoms coordinated with nitrogen. Notably, the interaction between Cu and N significantly improved the catalyst's adsorption capacity for NO3 − and NO2 −, thereby accelerating the reduction rate of NO3 − and effectively inhibiting the release of NO2 − intermediates Fig. 20 a. Compared to conventional Cu nanoparticles and bulk metals, this single-atom copper structure exhibited unique advantages, including enhanced adsorption and conversion of active species and remarkable stability in NRA. Gao et al. synthesized a structurally stable Th-MOF-supported single-atom copper catalyst (Cu@Th-BPYDC) by post-synthetic modification of crystalline bipyridyl thorium (Th-BPYDC) using a solid–liquid method [314]. Especially, single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis revealed that the Cu sites in this material possess a novel square-planar unsaturated coordination structure. It was found that in Cu@Th-BPYDC, the unsaturated coordination structure formed between Cu and the organic ligand significantly enhanced the electrocatalytic activity of the material Fig. 20b. In this catalyst, the Cu sites adopt a square-planar tetracoordinated configuration, serving as highly efficient active sites for NO3 − reduction. These sites exhibit high dispersion and density, which facilitates more effective binding of the active centers with NO3 − in solution, thereby promoting the electroreduction process. As expected, Cu@Th-BPYDC demonstrated excellent NO3 − electroreduction performance, achieving a high NH3 yield of 225.3 μmol h−1 cm−2 and a high FE of 94.5%. Besides, Ren and co-authors synthesized a Cu/Pd/CuO x heterogeneous structure material using a Pd-doped Cu-based MOF (CuPd-MOF) as the precursor catalyst through an in situ electrochemical reconstruction method [315]. This in-situ reconstruction technique altered the coordination environment of CuPd-MOF, further exposing more active sites for electrocatalytic NRA. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis indicated that partial electron transfer from Pd to Cu resulted in electron deficiency in Pd and electron enrichment in Cu (Fig. 20c). This unique electronic state not only facilitated NO3 − adsorption on Pd sites but also promoted further reduction on Cu sites while effectively suppressing HER. Ultimately, Cu/Pd/CuO x achieved an NH3 yield of 1510.3 μg h−1 mgcat −1 and a maximum FE of 84.04%. 4.6 Comparison of different types of catalysts Current research on cathode catalytic materials in the NRA system primarily focuses on metal catalysts, metal oxide catalysts, carbon-based non-metal catalysts, and composite electrocatalysts. Monometallic catalysts are extensively studied due to their specific active sites and simplified reaction mechanisms. However, their catalytic activity and selectivity are often constrained by the limitations of a single metal, resulting in poor adaptability to specific reactions. Building upon this, bimetallic catalysts exploit the synergistic effects between two metals, thereby significantly improving catalytic efficiency and product selectivity [316]. In bimetallic catalysts, the modification of the electronic structure and the shift in the Fermi level significantly enhance catalytic activity. By optimizing the metal ratio and arrangement, optimal performance can be achieved, demonstrating enhanced reaction control capabilities [317]. In recent years, high-entropy catalysts (HECs) have garnered significant attention owing to their numerous advantages, including elemental diversity, tunable structures and compositions, and a high density of intrinsic active sites [318]. HECs also display four key effects: high entropy effect, lattice distortion effect, slow diffusion effect, and cocktail effect. These effects collectively enhance their performance in multi-step electrocatalytic reactions [319]. However, the preparation of high-entropy catalysts is relatively complex, and controlling the activity and stability of surface elements remains challenging, which limits their broader adoption in industrial applications. Furthermore, metal catalysts incorporating noble metals may contribute to heavy metal pollution during both manufacturing and recycling processes, presenting a potential threat to the ecological environment. Metal oxide catalysts demonstrate high catalytic activity in NO3 − reduction reactions, attributed to their superior NO3 − adsorption capacity and remarkable ion exchange properties. Furthermore, most metal oxides are composed of abundant, earth-abundant elements and benefit from established large-scale production technologies. Therefore, the application of metal oxide catalysts in electrocatalytic ammonia synthesis offers economic advantages and encounters fewer barriers to industrialization [320]. However, the intrinsic semiconductor properties of metal oxides impede interfacial charge transfer, resulting in a low charge migration rate. Moreover, during extended electrocatalytic reactions, metal oxides are prone to chemical corrosion, which compromises their stability. This limits their practical application in long-term operations. In comparison to metal-based catalysts, carbon-based non-metal catalysts exhibit significant development potential owing to their high conductivity, low cost, excellent stability, and environmental sustainability [300,321]. The electrocatalytic activity of carbon materials can be significantly enhanced by incorporating heteroatoms, ions, or functional groups [322]. However, carbon-based catalysts still exhibit potential for improvement in reaction rate and catalytic activity. Composite electrocatalysts leverage the advantages of diverse materials, addressing the limitations of monometallic catalysts, particularly in enhancing nitrogen selectivity. By integrating the unique properties of various materials, synergistic effects are realized in catalytic performance. However, the preparation of composite electrocatalysts remains relatively complex, and large-scale production continues to face considerable challenges. Overall, each catalyst type presents distinct advantages and limitations in electrocatalytic NRA (Table 5 ). To enable practical application and economic viability, future research should concentrate on optimizing the performance of these catalysts, with particular emphasis on overcoming the current limitations in catalytic efficiency, stability, and scalability. 4.7 Electrocatalyst design strategies Building on the comprehensive discussion of catalyst research progress presented earlier, several catalyst design strategies have been proposed. The common strategies in electrocatalytic NRA are summarized as follows: the catalyst design approaches primarily focus on defect engineering, crystal facet regulation, and alloying [323]. Specifically, the defect engineering strategy focuses on introducing or adjusting defect sites in the catalyst to modify its electronic structure and surface properties, thereby influencing the adsorption behavior of reaction intermediates [256]. The core of this strategy is to optimize the electronic structure by regulating the offset of the band gap and the band center position [324]. Defect engineering can be categorized into various types, including heteroatom doping [325], vacancy-type defects, and surface functionalization. Each type exhibits distinct catalytic performance in the electrocatalytic NO3 − reduction process [326]. The introduction of defects is commonly achieved through methods such as high-temperature pyrolysis, irradiation treatment, and solvent (or hydrothermal) synthesis. Crystal facet engineering has proven to be an effective strategy for modulating the surface structure of catalysts and enhancing electrocatalytic performance. The atomic configuration of the crystal facets directly influences the number and nature of active sites [327]. For single-component nanoparticles, the precise exposure of specific crystal facets can accelerate electrochemical reactions. Particularly when multiple reactants and reaction pathways compete on the catalyst surface, the crystal facets play a crucial role in guiding the dominant reaction pathway due to their varying binding energies with intermediates. This enables the regulation of the catalyst's selectivity and activity [328]. Alloying is another important catalyst design strategy. By incorporating foreign metal elements to form alloy structures, the position of the d-band center in metal electrocatalysts can be adjusted, which has been widely used to optimize catalytic performance [329]. Based on d-band theory, the position of the d-band center in transition metal catalysts is crucial in determining the adsorption energy of key intermediates. The closer the d-band center is to the Fermi level, the fewer the anti-bonding states that are occupied, resulting in stronger adsorption of reactive species [330]. Combining active metals with auxiliary metals to construct bimetallic nanocatalysts is an effective method for modulating catalytic performance. This approach enables the fine-tuning of electronic properties, enhancing the adsorption and activation of reaction intermediates, and optimizing overall catalytic efficiency [331]. The modulation mechanisms include ligand effects, strain effects, and cooperative effects, among others. The choice of metal species can influence the adsorption behavior of active sites toward reaction intermediates, facilitate the formation of *H, and promote multi-electron transfer in the NRA reaction. Alloying strategies that combine both precious and non-precious metals have demonstrated superior activity and selectivity in electrocatalytic NRA compared to single-metal catalysts. In this system, transition metals function as co-catalysts to enhance NO3 − reduction, while precious metals serve to activate hydrogen atoms. 5 Quantification of NRA products and characterization techniques for reaction intermediates Quantitative analysis of electrocatalytic NRA products is essential for accurately determining key parameters, such as FE, reaction selectivity, and NO3 − conversion rate [332]. In addition to the diversity of products, the NRA process also generates a range of intermediates. The detection of these reactive intermediates is crucial for gaining insights into the reaction mechanisms. To achieve these objectives, this section will provide a summary of characterization techniques employed for the quantitative analysis of NH3 content and other key intermediates. 5.1 NH3 detection In the NRA process, NH3 is typically dissolved in the electrolyte as ammonium ions (NH4 +). Several analytical methods are commonly employed for the quantification of NH4 +, including ultraviolet–visible spectroscopy (UV–Vis), ion chromatography (IC), and proton nuclear magnetic resonance (1H NMR). Among these techniques, UV–Vis spectroscopy is the most widely used method, as it enables the determination of ion concentrations through the application of the Lambert-Beer law [333]. The two primary colorimetric reagents used for quantifying NH4 + are Nessler's reagent and indole phenol blue. Nessler's reagent reacts with NH3 to form a complex, which exhibits a characteristic absorption peak at 420 nm, allowing for the determination of NH4 + concentration [334], Indole phenol blue exhibits a maximum absorption wavelength at approximately 635 nm [335]. However, the maximum absorption wavelength may be influenced by factors such as the solution pH and variations in the spectrometer [336]. Therefore, the optimal measurement wavelength should be adjusted according to the specific conditions during the measurement process. Additionally, the concentration range of the solution must be carefully considered. IC is another widely used method for NH3 detection, based on ion exchange principles. IC offers advantages such as requiring small sample volumes, short measurement times, and a wide concentration detection range. The quantitative results obtained from both IC and UV–Vis methods are typically consistent, providing a means to verify the accuracy and reliability of the measurements. The 1H NMR method is often coupled with 15N isotope labeling experiments, offering significant advantages in determining the nitrogen source of the products [337]. By employing C4H4O4 as an internal standard, the integration area in 1H NMR can be standardized, enabling the tracking of the nitrogen source and the quantification of NH4 + concentration [338]. Zhang et al. utilized Cu clusters supported on TiO2 nanosheets with oxygen vacancies (10Cu-TiO2-x) as electrocatalysts for NRA [333]. They employed 15NO3 − and 14NO3 − as nitrogen sources. The 1H NMR spectra exhibited characteristic double and triple peaks for 15NH4 + and 14NH4 +, respectively·NH3 concentration was quantified using C4H4O4 as an external standard, and the accuracy of various quantification methods was subsequently verified. 5.2 Quantitative detection of reaction intermediates The intermediate products of NRA reactions can be categorized into gaseous products (H2, N2, NH3) and liquid products (NO2 −, NH4 +, NH2OH, N2H4). Gas chromatography (GC) is commonly employed for the quantitative detection of gaseous by-products or intermediates [332]. Particularly for N2 and H2, the two most competitive by-products in the NRA reaction, their accurate quantification is of critical importance. Additionally, mass spectrometry (MS) can also be utilized for the precise analysis of N2. For intermediates dissolved in the electrolyte, UV–Vis and colorimetric methods are commonly employed for detection. For instance, the detection of NO2 − typically involves the use of the Griess reagent. Upon adding the colorimetric agent, a standard curve is constructed by measuring the absorbance at 525 nm [339]. Additionally, to calculate the conversion rate of NO3 −, it is generally necessary to determine the concentration of NO3 − in the solution. This can be achieved using Ion Selective Electrode (ISE) methods or by adding sulfonic acid to the solution to induce color development, followed by quantification via UV–Vis spectroscopy [340]. Other by-products, such as NH2OH and N2H4, can also be detected by introducing specific color reagents, which induce absorbance in the ultraviolet range, thereby facilitating quantitative analysis. 5.3 In situ characterization of surface intermediates in catalyst To gain a deeper understanding of the mechanism and structure–activity relationship of catalysts, it is crucial to analyze the structural changes of surface intermediates during the electrocatalytic process. Traditional ex situ electrochemical methods have inherent limitations in elucidating the reaction mechanisms across various NH3 generation pathways. This has led to the development of in situ characterization techniques, which enable the direct probing of surface-active species and reaction intermediates on catalysts [341]. In situ characterization techniques integrate analytical methods with the ongoing reaction process, enabling real-time monitoring of changes occurring on the catalyst surface and providing direct, accurate information. Key in situ characterization techniques for surface intermediates on catalysts include in situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), in situ differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS), and in situ Raman spectroscopy [342]. FTIR is an infrared spectroscopy technique used to analyze the absorbance or emissivity of samples [343]. By exciting the vibrations and rotations of chemical bonds within a molecule, FTIR monitors changes in the molecular dipole moment, thereby providing insights into the molecular structure of the substance [344]. In FTIR spectra, absorption peaks at distinct wavenumbers correspond to specific chemical bonds or functional groups. The intensity of these peaks evolves throughout the reaction, providing insights into the formation or consumption of intermediates. In the study by Liu et al., in situ FTIR was effectively employed to characterize the reduction process of NO3 − on the surface of Rh@Cu catalysts (Fig. 21 a) [236]. In Cu nanowires, the FTIR spectrum only detected a weak absorption peak corresponding to the –NH2 group. However, upon introducing Rh single-atom clusters into the electrocatalyst, a prominent –NH2 peak appeared in the FTIR spectrum. Given that Rh catalysts exhibit an optimal ΔG for hydrogen adsorption, it is inferred that the introduction of Rh significantly enhanced hydrogen adsorption on the electrode surface. This finding indicates that the hydrogenation step is no longer the rate-limiting step in the reduction of NO3 − on the catalyst surface. DEMS is an online detection technique that integrates mass spectrometry analysis with electrochemical processes, which is commonly employed for in-situ analysis of volatile gas products generated during electrochemical reactions. It enables real-time detection of reaction products and intermediates, providing valuable insights into reaction pathways and transformation mechanisms [345]. Based on the mass-to-charge ratio (m/z) of different substances, the mass spectrometer records the signals of each component in chronological order, thereby generating the mass spectrum of the gas products. In contemporary research, DEMS plays a crucial role in both qualitative and quantitative analyses of electrochemical reaction mechanisms. Yin et al. employed in situ DEMS to monitor the electrocatalytic NRA on Ag/Cu2O hybrids and Cu2O [346]. The results indicated that, within the same voltage range, the formation of the intermediate NH2OH was suppressed on the Ag/Cu2O hybrid, while it was clearly observed on Cu2O. This suggests that the two catalysts exhibit distinct reaction pathways (Fig. 21b). By comparing the DEMS results with DFT calculations and correlating them with experimental data on the actual NH3 synthesis performance of different materials, the study revealed that the strong interfacial interaction between Ag nanoparticles and Cu2O effectively suppressed the formation of *NOH, while promoting the generation of *N. In situ Raman spectroscopy is a characterization technique based on the scattering of light on the surface of materials [347]. Raman shift is determined by changes in molecular vibrational energy levels. Since different chemical bonds and functional groups have characteristic vibrational modes, Raman spectroscopy can be employed for the qualitative analysis of the structural composition and chemical environment of materials [348]. With the advancement of technology, Raman spectroscopy has progressively evolved into several advanced variants, including Surface-Enhanced Raman Spectroscopy (SERS), Shell-Isolated Nanoparticle-Enhanced Raman Spectroscopy (SHINERS), and Tip-Enhanced Raman Spectroscopy (TERS). Liu et al. reported a tandem catalytic system that integrates Cu single-atom catalysts with adjacent Co3O4 nanosheets and employed in situ Raman spectroscopy to investigate the reaction characteristics of Co3O4/Cu1-N-C and Cu1-N-C under −0.8 V vs. RHE conditions (Fig. 21c) [349]. The results showed that a distinct peak attributed to NO2 − was detected on the surface of Cu1-N-C, while the NO2 − signal on Co3O4/Cu1-N-C was negligible, indicating that Co3O4 promotes the further conversion of NO2 −. Mechanistic studies revealed that Co3O4 accelerates the electroreduction of NO3 − to NH3 by modulating the adsorption configuration of NO2 − and enhancing its binding strength. This accelerates the electroreduction of NO3 − to NH3. In addition to the aforementioned in situ characterization techniques, various other in situ analytical methods have also been employed to study intermediate reaction reactions, including in situ IC and in situ Electron Spin Resonance (ESR). With the advancement of in situ characterization techniques, an increasing number of emerging methods are expected to be widely applied for the in-depth analysis of catalytic mechanisms, providing crucial support for catalyst design and optimization of the reaction process. 6 Challenges in electrocatalytic nitrate reduction Despite rigorous investigations into the materials and influencing factors of electrocatalytic NRA at both theoretical and experimental levels, the field persists in facing numerous challenges. To facilitate the NO3 −-to-NH4 + conversion and large-scale commercial applications, several pivotal challenges remain to be addressed. The ensuing discussion delineates the principal challenges confronting researchers and proposes future research trajectories. (1) Electrocatalytic NRA is a multi-step process involving intricate electron and proton transfer steps, during which various unstable intermediates are formed. The presence of these intermediates has a substantial impact on the efficiency of NO3 − reduction and the distribution of the final products. Effectively controlling the formation and transformation of these intermediates remains a significant challenge due to their short lifetimes, intricate reaction pathways, and the difficulty in selectively producing the desired products. Therefore, the development of advanced in situ characterization techniques is crucial for addressing these challenges. By integrating in situ spectroscopy, electrochemical characterization, and high-resolution imaging methods, the reaction profile during NO3 − reduction can be elucidated, uncovering the structure–activity relationship of the reaction. Research in this area offers valuable insights into the fundamental principles of catalytic reactions and is essential for advancing electrocatalytic NO3 − reduction technology. (2) Active sites of electrocatalysts are key to catalyzing NRA reactions [350,351]. Due to the application of electric potential and variations in the reaction environment, the active sites of catalysts often undergo structural reorganization, which can significantly influence their performance. However, current research primarily focuses on the dynamic evolution of electrocatalysts under static electric potentials and fixed reaction conditions, with limited attention given to the evolution of dynamic active sites. Investigating dynamic active sites is crucial for uncovering the intrinsic structure–property relationships of catalysts and offers a deeper understanding of the interactions between electrocatalysts and electrochemical reactions [352]. Pulse potential driving can change the electronic structure of the catalytic surface and the distribution of active sites, improve the interaction between reactants and active sites, and promote the synthesis of NH3 [353]. Advanced in situ characterization techniques enable real-time monitoring of the dynamic behavior of catalysts and reaction intermediates, providing crucial support for the study of dynamic active sites [354]. At the same time, during the electrocatalytic process, the adsorption strength of Hads is an important factor affecting catalytic efficiency. Excessively high Hads adsorption strength may occupy too many catalytic active sites, hindering the complete reduction of NO3 − and leading to a decrease in conversion efficiency. According to the Sabatier principle, the adsorption strength of NO3 − on the electrode surface should also be maintained within a moderate range to ensure the smooth progression of the reaction. Optimizing the adsorption strengths of Hads and NO3 − by regulating the electronic structure of the catalyst becomes an effective strategy to improve catalytic efficiency, optimize reaction selectivity, and enhance conversion rates. (3) Current research demonstrates that various types of NRA electrocatalysts have been developed; however, they still encounter substantial challenges regarding industrial application. While most studies have concentrated on enhancing the stability, activity, and selectivity of catalysts to achieve optimal performance under laboratory conditions, catalyst performance can be significantly influenced by numerous factors in complex reaction systems during large-scale practical operations [355]. Furthermore, the durability of catalysts under prolonged operational conditions remains an unresolved challenge [356]. In practical reaction processes, catalysts are frequently affected by factors such as the electrolyte environment, operating conditions (including temperature, pressure, high current density, and potential fluctuations), and the presence of by-products. These variables can cause catalyst poisoning or degradation, leading to a reduction in catalytic performance. Additionally, the design and synthesis costs of catalysts represent critical challenges that hinder their industrial scalability. Consequently, a key issue for the practical deployment of NRA electrocatalysts is to improve both the stability and selectivity of the catalysts, while preserving high catalytic performance and reducing production costs. (4) In the electrocatalytic NRA process, energy consumption substantially influences the sustainability and economic advantages of the electrocatalytic system. To minimize energy consumption and enhance energy conversion efficiency, efficient electrocatalytic processes must be conducted at lower overpotentials. This not only challenges the activity and stability of the catalyst but also necessitates precise control over the electrode materials and electrolytes within the electrochemical system. This includes selecting electrode materials with excellent electrical conductivity and chemical stability, as well as designing electrolyte systems capable of effectively transferring electrons and protons. In this context, the microstructure of electrode surfaces and the interactions at electrochemical interfaces play a crucial role in influencing energy consumption and efficiency. Therefore, comprehensive optimization of the electrochemical system is essential for achieving the commercialization and sustainable development of electrocatalytic NRA technology. (5) Despite the potential of electrocatalytic NRA technology to convert nitrates into valuable products demonstrated in theoretical and experimental studies, its transition to large-scale applications faces both technical and economic challenges. Improving cost-effectiveness not only depends on reducing raw material and operational costs but also on fully considering the system's long-term operational stability, maintenance costs, and potential environmental impacts and treatment expenses. Moreover, the large-scale application of electrochemical NRA technology must address the enhancement of market competitiveness, including market demand for products, commercialization model of the technology, and competitive relationship with existing technologies. Therefore, conducting an in-depth analysis of the economic viability of electrochemical NRA technology and evaluating its economic feasibility in different application scenarios are critical steps toward driving its commercialization. 7 Conclusions and perspectives This review comprehensively summarizes recent advancements in electrocatalytic NRA, systematically analyzing reaction mechanisms, key influencing factors, electrocatalyst design strategies, and the challenges encountered in current technological developments. The primary goal of this review is to promote the sustainable utilization of nitrogen resources and to facilitate the practical application of electrocatalytic technology.
