Through an in-depth examination of reaction mechanisms and optimization strategies, this review offers both theoretical insights and practical recommendations to drive NH3 synthesis technology toward greater efficiency, environmental sustainability, and long-term viability. (1) The NRA process provides an innovative and mutually beneficial strategy for environmental remediation and resource recovery. In this intricate reaction, the synergistic interactions between electron and proton transfer at the catalyst surface not only influence the reaction kinetics but also play a crucial role in determining the selectivity and efficiency of the process. A deeper understanding of the fundamental reaction mechanisms of electrocatalytic NRA will establish a solid theoretical basis for optimizing the electrocatalytic process. With the continuous advancement of technology, integrating advanced in situ characterization techniques with electrocatalytic NRA research to monitor the real-time electron and proton transfer processes during the reaction and to elucidate the evolution pathways of intermediate products will offer forward-thinking guidance for achieving a more efficient and highly selective NH3 synthesis process. (2) The performance and selectivity of electrocatalytic NRA are influenced by a range of factors, including the composition of the electrolyte, applied potential, properties of electrode materials, and the design of the reactor structure. Typically, the NRA reaction is conducted in alkaline or neutral environments, where a more negative potential is applied to suppress the HER. However, excessively high negative potentials may also lead to the formation of side products, such as NO2 −. When optimizing the potential, it is crucial to balance reaction selectivity with the impact of these side products. At the same time, optimizing the reactor structure is expected to further enhance the overall performance of the reaction. From a practical application perspective, due to their higher NH3 production rates, dual-chamber cells and flow cell reactors have become more promising options. By comprehensively considering these influencing factors, optimizing reaction conditions, and innovatively designing catalysts for specific application scenarios, more efficient and sustainable solutions for NO3 − reduction and NH3 recovery can be achieved. (3) Electrocatalysts play a pivotal role in the NRA process by promoting the efficient reduction of NO3 −. While pure metal catalysts have garnered significant attention due to their excellent electrocatalytic activity, their high cost and the limited availability of precious metals hinder their widespread application. In contrast, non-precious metals such as Fe, Cu, Ni, and Co are favored as alternatives for their cost-effectiveness and satisfactory performance. Metal oxides and carbon-based non-metallic catalysts also demonstrate significant potential in NRA due to their unique properties. Composite electrocatalysts integrate the advantages of both metal and non-metal materials, offering new avenues to enhance the performance of NH3 synthesis. By employing strategies such as heteroatom doping, defect engineering, interface engineering, and alloying, the electronic structure and surface properties of catalysts can be finely tuned, enabling the design of optimized catalysts. Theoretically-guided catalyst design, as a promising strategy for enhancing catalyst performance, merits broader application and further investigation in future research. (4) The application of electrocatalytic technology in the large-scale industrial synthesis of NH3 requires overcoming challenges related to system integration and engineering implementation. This involves optimizing reactor design, enhancing current efficiency, increasing yield, and improving catalyst preparation and loading. Additionally, integrating sustainable processes, such as renewable energy utilization and wastewater resource recovery, can further enhance the system's environmental friendliness, promoting a low-carbon, green pathway for NH3 production. Simultaneously, it is imperative to conduct a comprehensive evaluation of factors such as economic viability, resource utilization efficiency, and long-term sustainability to ensure that electrochemical technology maintains its competitiveness during the commercialization phase. Overall, electrocatalytic NRA, as an emerging technology for ammonia synthesis, presents significant potential for practical application. Future research will prioritize tackling critical challenges, including enhancing catalyst performance and stability, optimizing reactor design, and advancing system integration, with the ultimate goal of facilitating the industrial application of this technology. Additionally, efforts will be directed toward the development of more efficient, environmentally sustainable, and economically viable pathways for ammonia synthesis. He obtained a Bachelor's degree in applied chemistry from North China Electric Power University (Baoding) in 2024. His current research focuses on the electrochemical synthesis of ammonia and plasma energy conversion. Tianyu Li received his Master's degree in electrical engineering from Xi'an Jiaotong University. He is now a doctoral student at the School of Electrical Engineering, Xi'an Jiaotong University. His main research interest is plasmacatalysis. Yuting Gao entered Xi'an Jiaotong University to pursue a PhD in 2022. Currently, her research focuses on applications in the fields of plasma-liquid interactions and plasma energy conversion. Jieping Fan is currently a PhD candidate at Xi'an Jiaotong University in China. Her main research area is plasma-catalyzed green energy production. Dingwei Gan is a PhD candidate at Xi'an Jiaotong University. He received his Master's degree from Ningbo University. He was awarded the 2024 National Natural Science Foundation (Doctor) Program. His current research focuses on prebiotic chemistry and plasma energy chemistry. Shuai Yuan is currently pursuing a Master's degree in electrical engineering at Xi'an Jiaotong University. He obtained a Bachelor's degree in transportation from Chang'an University in 2024. His research expertise lies in the methods of plasma bubble degradation of antibiotics. Longfei Hong is currently pursuing a Master's degree at the School of Electrical Engineering, Xi'an Jiaotong University, China. His research focuses on plasma energy conversion and the origin of life in the presence of plasma. Yue Feng received her Bachelor's degree from Zhengzhou University in 2021. She then enrolled at Xi'an Jiaotong University to pursue her PhD degree at China University of Petroleum (East China). Currently, her research interests are the design and development of ammonia synthesis plants for plasma-catalyzed. Jing Sun got her PhD from the University of New South Wales (UNSW), Australia. Her research interests include plasma gas conversion and electrocatalysis with their applications in sustainable ammonia and fertilizers production. Qiang Song received his MSc from Shandong University. His research focuses on the tandem plasma-electrocatalytic process for energy conversion. Tianqi Zhang got his BSc from Wuhan University and PhD from the University of Sydney. He was also awarded the Australian Research Council (ARC) Discovery Early Career Researcher Awards (DECRA) and worked as Lecturer at the University of Sydney. His research interests include plasma-liquid interaction, plasma gas conversion, and plasma catalytic reactions. He earned his PhD from the University of Wollongong in 2013. His research expertise spans plasma gas conversion, additive manufacturing, biomimetic systems, electrochemical device fabrication, and plasma catalysis, with a strong focus on green ammonia production, sustainable fertilizers, and hydrogen technologies. Patrick J. Cullen is a Professor at the School of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering, University of Sydney. His research interests include the development of electrically driven green chemistry with a focus on non-equilibrium plasma, plasma catalysis, and plasma-electrochemical technologies. Green ammonia synthesis and technology scaleup are applications of particular interest of his research group. Renwu Zhou is currently a Professor at Xi'an Jiaotong University, China. His main research background lies in the area of plasma chemistry and plasma-enabled catalysis for green energy production.

coredata.dc:description: Ammonia is the cornerstone of modern agriculture, providing a critical nitrogen source for global food production and serving as a key raw material for numerous industrial chemicals. Electrocatalytic nitrate reduction, as an environmentally friendly method for synthesizing ammonia, not only mitigates the reliance on current ammonia synthesis processes fed by traditional fossil fuels but also effectively reduces nitrate pollution resulting from agricultural and industrial activities. This review explores the fundamental principles of electrocatalytic nitrate reduction, focusing on the key steps of electron transfer and ammonia formation. Additionally, it summarizes the critical factors influencing the performance and selectivity of the reaction, including the properties of the electrolyte, operating voltage, electrode materials, and design of the electrolytic cell. Further discussion of recent advances in electrocatalysts, including pure metal catalysts, metal oxide catalysts, non-metallic catalysts, and composite catalysts, highlights their significant roles in enhancing both the efficiency and selectivity of electrocatalytic nitrate to ammonia (NRA) reactions. Critical challenges for the industrial NRA trials and further outlooks are outlined to propel this strategy toward real-world applications. Overall, the review provides an in-depth overview and comprehensive understanding of electrocatalytic NRA technology, thereby promoting further advancements and innovations in this domain.
